column16:
After my websearch I learnt about PAD,  PAD is is plaque buildup in your leg arteries. Your leg arteries carry oxygen and nutrient-rich blood from your heart to your arms and legs. Other names for this are peripheral vascular disease or peripheral arterial disease. I also learned about the symptoms, diagnosis and treatment and that gave me confidence that the correct method of treatment was A. Treating PAD, for some people with more severe PAD, leg pain may still cause problems in daily life, even after a few months of exercise and medications. In more severe cases, people need to improve their blood flow to relieve pain at rest or to heal a wound.

More advanced PAD that’s causing severe pain and limited mobility may require endovascular (minimally invasive) or surgical treatment. Some heart disease treatments also treat peripheral artery disease, including:

Angioplasty.
Stents.
Peripheral artery bypass surgery.
Atherectomy.

From my research, Lower extremity Angioplasty is a test that uses X-rays and contrast dye to see the arteries that carry blood to the legs. It’s used to look for narrowed or blocked areas in leg arteries that can cause leg pain when walking. This aligns perfectly with the AI's answer and this was why I choose the final probability

From my research, I found out that in a case of mental incapacity, different tests to determine whether a person had the mental capacity to enter into a contract. 
An example of such test is called the "affective test". using the affective test, a contract can be voided if one party is unable to act in a reasonable manner and the other party has reason to know of the condition.

column16: I settled on choice (A) with a probability of 98% after extensive research. The declaration of the co-passenger describing the assertion made by the respondent "Our return journey was from a social event where alcoholic beverages were consumed in significant quantities by all attendees" would commonly be viewed as prattle under US regulation. Hearsay is a statement made outside of court to back up the claims made in the statement. In this instance, the assertion was made by the co-passenger. The statement asserts that everyone at the social event consumed a significant amount of alcoholic beverages. The arraignment needs to utilize this assertion to demonstrate that the respondent was working the engine vehicle while intensely affected by liquor.  Although there are exceptions to the hearsay rule that allow certain out-of-court statements to be admitted as evidence (such as statements against interest, excited utterances, present sense impressions, and so on), the co-passenger's statement in this case does not clearly fall under any of these exceptions. It does not contradict the co-passenger's interests. It's anything but an energized expression made under the pressure of the occasion. It's anything but a current sense impression depicting an occasion or condition. Therefore, the statement would likely be excluded from consideration as hearsay and would not be admissible in court unless there are specific circumstances or legal arguments that can establish this statement as falling within an exception to the hearsay rule (which are not evident from the information provided).

column16: The AI's answer is correct. The US law doesn't expressly prevent minors from testify in a court of law. This is explained under Rule 601 in the Federal . However, a minor's competency to testify, especially is such a serious matter, would be assessed by a judge before doing so. The judge or jury must assess the minor's cognitive development, ability to differentiate right from wrong, handle emotions that come with cross examination, among others. Also, the fact that the child suffered severe trauma from the tragic event is a factor that the judge would consider before allowing the minor to testify at the witness stand.

column16: The AI's answer is correct. Its difficult for a court to accept hearsay as form of evidence but there are some exceptions to this rule. One of them is the declaration against self interest. The argument here is that one cant fabricate statements that are incriminating to themselves. Such statements not even need to be formal. Moreover, this alleged statement could also be easily considered as a form excited utterance and thus increasing its admissibility in the court as evidence. On the other hand, this statement falls short of that of a co-conspirator as explained Rule 801(d). This is so because there needs to be proof brought before the court to support the conspiracy and also such a statement needs to have been made during the act rather than after as it is in this case.

column16: I settled on choice (B) with a probability of 99%. The professional is attempting to assess the supraspinatus muscle. The supraspinatus muscle is one of the rotator cuff muscles situated on the back part of the scapula. The supraspinatus muscle is answerable for starting abduction of the arm (first 15°-30°) and settling the shoulder joint. The particular move portrayed in the inquiry is known as the empty can test or Jobe test, which is utilized to survey the strength and uprightness of the supraspinatus muscle. During the empty can test, the specialist requests that the patient abduct the arm to 90° in the plane of the scapula (scaption), with the thumbs pointing lower (like emptying a can). This particular situating disconnects the supraspinatus muscle. The test assesses whether the patient can oppose downward pressure applied to the arm in this position, and tests the strength of the supraspinatus muscle. Hence, in this situation, the expert is attempting to evaluate the capability and strength of the supraspinatus muscle utilizing the empty can test.

column16:
I searched in google "us law child as a witness definition"  wanting to find out how old child needs to be to become w witness in US. 
This search lead me to a web with an article "Understanding the Role of Age in Children’s Testimony in Court Proceedings in the United States" .
In this article, it's well expained, that childern age and ability to provide credible testimony are significant factors that must be taken into account in the court. 
It also point out, thatr "n this age group may have limited language skills, memory recall abilities, and an increased susceptibility to suggestibilit" which confirm anwser B of AI. 

I also checked another web just to double check the correctness of this article, and followin was found
 "In most states and in federal court, all children are presumed competent to testify, unless shown otherwise. A child is competent to testify if they can:
recall events accurately
communicate sufficiently
understand the difference between truth and lies, and
understand the importance of testifying truthfully.

The judge will often ask age-appropriate questions to find out if the child understands the importance of telling the truth" 

The above also confirm, AI anwser and my feelings about correct anwser.

column16: After my research, I think that AI may be wrong. Explanation of the Hearsay says " The basic concept is that a statement made out of court to a witness cannot be used to establish the truth of the statement. This is because the opposing party does not have a chance to cross-examine the person who made the statement and test their credibility " or "This type of evidence is known as Hearsay, i.e. evidence intended to prove something as true from a witness who is not in court to give that testimony him/herself. " In our case The co-passenger, who made the statement, is ready and available to deliver their testimony during the court trial. This makes me think, this is not a hearsay, therefore can not be excluded from consideration, as it falls within the category of hearsay.

First, I went with the AI anwser but during my research, I found information that Undue influence needs to be proven in court by "Submit proof. This includes providing evidence of coercion, identifying how undue influence has occurred, and giving evidence. Confirmation will be in written affidavits, witness testimony, and any relevant station you can acquire.
In regard to undue influence, you’ll need to be able to provide proof of threats made to the deceased, the withholding of food or medicine, or outright fraud—any fraud that would have had the deceased change their will under false pretenses. Witness testimony could include family members or other close associates describing incidents of seeing the deceased being isolated or otherwise pressured.". In our case, witnesses or any other form of evidence is not mentioned so I belive this would be difficult to prove. I did not find much information that would make me sure about Insufficient consideration but following explanation from AI this coud be more possible. "Erythromycin is an antibiotic. It's widely used to treat chest infections, such as pneumonia, skin conditions, such as acne and rosacea, dental abscesses, and sexually transmitted infections." 
"A nasogastric (NG) tube is a thin, soft tube made of plastic or rubber that is passed through the nose, down through the throat, and into the stomach. It is used to deliver food or medicine to the stomach for people who have difficulty eating or swallowing. It can also be used to remove liquids or air from the stomach." 

In our case patient has multiple air-fluid levels which can be removed by a nasogastric tube. 

One of the articles for Erythromycin mentioned  also treating digestive system and tratment of Gastroparesis which is "paralysis of the stomach. It’s a functional disorder affecting your stomach nerves and muscles. It makes your stomach muscle contractions weaker and slower than they need to be to digest your food and pass it on to your intestines. This leads to food sitting too long in your stomach." Despite that, I stronlgy belive first a nasogastric tube needs to be used to get rid of the air from the stomac.

column16:
In the artice about WHAT IS ADMISSION BY SILENCE? it's  writen that:

"In most cases, admission by silence is not admissible in court. However, there are limited exceptions. First and foremost, evidence of a defendant’s silence can only be introduced against a defendant who was not under arrest at the time the accusation was made.

Once a person has been read their Miranda rights or is taken into custody by police or other law enforcement officers, the prosecutor cannot introduce evidence of a defendant’s silence, and a jury cannot use it to infer guilt" 

Above means that accused B from our case did not have to say anything. He could remind silent and this was his right which can not be taked as the evidence in the court. 

Anwser B is correct.

I reaserched information to check if contracts can be adjusted verbaly. Articles that I found clearly states that if sale ( in our case the constraction) is above $500 modifications can not be done verbally.

"The statute of frauds limits how certain contracts can be modified. It prevents oral modification of all contracts:
for the sale of goods over $500
that assign responsibility to one party for another party’s debt
for the sale or transfer of land
that will take more than a year to perform
If your contract meets any of the above criteria, it is impossible, even if so desired by the parties, to modify orally."

So AI was right about The statute of frauds where it clearly says about value of the goods which in our case is much higher than %500. 

I found another article that has specify exacly the same. 

Oral modifications are possible but if none of the above ascanrios apply. 
Not in our case then.

I researched about verbal contracts and they are very difficult to proof. In our case we would not be able to proof the agreement on any of the below options. There was not even money exchange yet. : 
"Some options are available for one party to provide proof. These include:
Evidence to the court of the plaintiff's performance of services called for in the contract
Proof of any money exchange showing a deal was made
Proof of a loan and payments
A check written as a down payment or deposit
Witnesses present at the time the agreement was made
Documentation such as mail correspondence, emails, and text messages corroborating your testimony
Enforcing a verbal contract is one of the more complicated cases because of varying elements in each individual case and lack of written agreement. "

in the article Burn Resuscitation and Management it clerly state, that:
 "Patients with burns of more than 20% - 25% of their body surface should be managed with aggressive IV fluid resuscitation to prevent “burn shock."
In our case patient has 43% of burn. 

Also found this confirming AI anwser: 
Severe burns cause not only significant injury at the local burn site but ....., intravascular fluid loss, and large fluid shifts. These responses occur mostly over the first 24 hours peaking at around six to eight hours after injury. This response, along with decreased cardiac output and increased vascular resistance, can lead to marked hypovolemia and hypoperfusion called burn shock. This can be managed with aggressive fluid resuscitation.

I also checked what is the endotracheal tube used for:
"t is typically placed when a person is unable to breathe on their own."

In our case the patient is not having problems with breathing. There is premature ventricular contractions but it's occasional.

Imaging studies are frequently used to support the diagnosis of infection in acutely ill patients. Structural imaging studies include plain radiography, ultrasound, CT, and MRI. These methods can establish the presence of abnormal tissue or fluid collections that often accompany bacterial infection.
CT scans use electromagnetic radiation to take a series of X-rays of the interior structures of the ear and create a computerized three-dimensional image. CT scans may reveal damage to the bony components of the ear or an abnormal bone growth in the middle ear, a condition called otosclerosis.

Except for a criminal conviction under Rule 609, extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness’s conduct in order to attack or support the witness’s character for truthfulness. But the court may, on cross-examination, allow them to be inquired into if they are probative of the character for truthfulness or untruthfulness of:

(1) the witness; or

(2) another witness whose character the witness being cross-examined has testified about.

When first reading the question and possible answers, I was unsure of the relevance of answer A, but then through my research it kind of confirmed this. 

First, I wanted to know the foundations of the admissibility of camera and surveillance footage relevance in a court case in the US. It confirmed that it is, if relevance and authenticity can be demonstrated, which I believe in this scenario they can. There are a handful foundations that the footage could be found inadmissible, which the most common are: 

(1) Undue Prejudice: An attorney can argue that the photo or video evidence is not a reasonable representation of its subject and may result in undue prejudice. 

(2) Hearsay: If there is no witness present who can be cross-examined, an attorney can argue that the substance of the photo or video evidence is hearsay. 

(3) The Best Evidence Rule: If the photo or video is secondary evidence (a copy or facsimile), an attorney can argue that the original copy is superior evidence. 

(4) Lack of Foundation: When visibility, the time of day, the weather or some other factor is at issue in the litigation, an attorney can question a substantial similarity between the occurrence in question and the photo or video evidence.

I thought at this point there was no chance that the footage could be inadmissible. So, I then had a look at the Confrontation Clause of the Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution, which again, felt irrelevant. This rule states that "in all criminal prosecutions, the accused shall enjoy the right... to be confronted with the witnesses against him," which sure, but that isn't in question here.

So, this is how I came to the conclusion that B was 100% the correct answer.

This scenario was difficult to research as I couldn't find much case law about it. However, my first step was to go back to the Rules that pertain to evidence and hearsay, and figure out whether what the pedestrian stated was even admissible in the first place.

It became clear that under the Federal Rules of Evidence, a dying declaration is admissible if the proponent of the statement can establish all of the following:

* The declarant's statement is being offered in a criminal prosecution for homicide, or in a civil action. Some states also permit the admission of dying declarations in other types of cases.
* The declarant is unavailable – this can be established (in this case, they've died)
* The declarant's statement was made while under the genuine belief that their death was imminent. Although, the declarant does not have to actually die.
* The declarant's statement relates to the cause or circumstances of what they believed to be their impending death.

So in consideration of the above, the pedestrian's statement does seem admissible as long as we can establish that they genuinely believed that they were going to die. This is where the affidavit became more significant, as I knew now that I needed to establish whether the affidavit of the trainee doctor is also admissible as evidence to confirm that the pedestrian had this belief, which I found the following for:

"While an affidavit is admissible evidence, many courts may deem it hearsay or unreliable and require that you testify to the affidavit to avoid this distinction," and "... It is worth noting that affidavits and witnesses provide the court with valuable information regarding what has happened and eliminates time consuming procedures. It is not about what the individual feels or thinks about what happened. This means that if your affidavit contains speculation or arguments, the court may refuse to consider it."

In saying this, because the affidavit contains information that the trainee doctor directly witnessed (not speculation), and is directly relevant to establishing the dying declaration exception, I believe it should be considered by the court - answer A. I'm not super confident on this one, which is why I have placed a not-so-confident probability.

Many resources reiterated this same notion that: ‌‌‌An agreement can be made over the phone, via email, or letter, but an ironclad contract must be identical in everyone’s office before it is signed.

Another aspect of this is that jurisdictions differ on their use of "agreement" in denoting a legally enforceable contract. For example, the Supreme Court of Washington has stated that a contract is a promise or set of promises which is protected under the law, whereas an agreement is a manifestation of mutual assent which does not necessarily carry legal implications.

As stated above, agreements do differ to formal contracts when it comes to enforceability, so while I did not entirely agree with answer A in that the nephew could successfully sue the uncle (particularly as it's real estate related), I definitely felt like it was a far more accurate response over Answer B.

I think I was a little misfocused during a lot of this research as I kept circling back to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, which is the primary authority dealing with US citizens' pensions.

Eventually, I did find relevant material in Promissory Estoppel, which I believe applies in this situation due to the requirements being the following:

1. The promisor made a promise, with the intention that a reasonable person would act on it;
2. The promisee believed the promisor, and acted on that promise in good faith;
3. The promisor later reneged on that promise causing financial harm to the promisee; and
4. The nature of the promise is such that the only way to avoid injustice is by enforcing the promise.

My initial thought is that I wanted to establish the difference between the high-energy bladder dome trauma symptoms and high-energy urethra trauma symptoms. Generally speaking, many of the symptoms do line up, however there were some distinguishing factors.

The main thing that made me think it was definitely a bladder dome injury is the use of a catheter. In urethra trauma, not being able to pass a tube into the urethra is the first sign of urethral injury, and a Foley catheter goes directly into the urethra, which they were able to do in this scenario.

Bladder dome trauma is considered relatively common in car accidents, especially when the person has a full bladder. One can assume that the patient being drunk, they likely had a pretty full bladder from the alcohol. No blood being present in the urethral meatus also indicates that the injury comes from somewhere more internally, like the bladder dome.

Overall, I wasn't the most confident, but fairly certain, so I placed my probabilities as A - 20% and B - 80%.

column16:
The first step I decided to establish whether the car dealership had indeed acted fraudulently. It was clear that they knowingly did not disclose the damage. In many jurisdictions, if a car dealer intentionally withholds information regarding substantial physical damage, such as a bent frame or a significant mechanical issue, it is considered a material misrepresentation and may constitute a violation of statute.

An example could be the law in New Jersey that requires complete fair and honest disclosure if the seller even slightly believes that the disclosure would make a difference in the customer's purchasing decision. If the seller omits a material fact from a transaction they are responsible. If they mislead the customer they are responsible. If the seller of the vehicle misrepresents the history of vehicle or misrepresents the condition of the vehicle they are liable under most circumstances.

On the other hand, unconscionability can arise when the terms of a contract so unreasonably favour the stronger party to the point of being oppressive that the court feels the need to intervene - this was not the case. The buyer was not oppressed, just misled.

So I believe A 100% and B 0%.

column16:
Undue influence felt entirely more appropriate following my research. Many resources provided an outline for the foundations of undue influence, which include:

* Vulnerability of the victim: Evidence of vulnerability may include, but is not limited to... emotional distress, isolation, illness disability, etc... Where the influencer knew of, or should have known of, the alleged victim’s vulnerability.

* The influencer’s apparent authority: Evidence of apparently authority may include... family member.

* The actions or tactics used by the influencer: Evidence of actions or tactics used may include, but is not limited to... Use of affection, intimidation, or coercion.

* The equity of the result: Evidence of the equity of the result may include... economic consequences to the victim, any divergence from the victim’s prior intent or course of conduct or dealing.

All of these factors seem to be relevant for this situation. Further, although I believe insufficient (or inadequate) consideration was given, I believe this would be more of a contention between the parties. Due to the mother passing away, I believe the more likely successful case rests on the son proving undue influence, which could be substantiated by medical staff etc.

Although I found the actual reasoning of the two answers both fairly relevant, I decided on answer B ultimately. 

In my research I found that acceptance of a unilateral contract happens when the offeree performs their part of the contract. It's not enough for the offeree to begin to perform — the offeree must complete the required performance. So in this sense, answer A is actually the more likely of the two. However, we're arguing about the bank's revocation of their offer and whether the customer can sue on this basis. 

In a unilateral contract, the offeror may revoke the offer before the offeree's performance begins. Our scenario demonstrates that they revoked the offer while the customer was not already performing their part of the contract, but had nearly completed performance (or had completed performance) of the contract, thus giving them a claim.

This is probably one of the more difficult Lojban questions in the group. In terms of researching, I wanted to first understand the major differences between the use of "bu'u" and "ne'i" in the language. There was a lot of supporting information for the word "bu'u" being "at", while on the other hand, "ne'i" showed up being defined as "within", but I couldn't actually find any sentence examples that used the term "ne'i".

One of the important sentences I found that made me sway toward "bu'u" was the following: 

lei rirni pu zvati le barja .i ca bo lei verba cu kansa no da bu'u le zdani — The parents were in the bar; meanwhile the children were alone at home.

"Zvarti" is used for "in", while "bu'u" is used for "at". Again, I found other examples that used "zvarti" over "ne'i" and still couldn't find supporting evidence for "ne'i" other than the following definition:

ne'i - location tense relation/direction; within/inside of/into ...

This feels like it *could* be correct but I truly couldn't find any supporting sentences or usage examples, so I've gone with my gut in opting for A, "bu'u".

This was an interesting one as the explanation of the patient's symptoms didn't quite fit the symptoms of a varicocele, nor did they fit any of the symptoms of testicular cancer. First, I wanted to understand the different types of growth that can occur on a man's testicles, which there was several. 

Varicocele seemed to mostly fit the description with its "bag of worms" texture, but there were a couple of inconsistencies:

- Varicocele should reduce in size or disappear when lying down.
- Normally appear on the left side. Right-side varicocele are rare (which this patient presented with a right-side growth).

For testicular cancer, the characteristics are:

- Generally a small, hard lump.
- Presents itself alongside other pain symptoms, like soreness or tenderness of the testicles.

In terms of treatments, it only appears that CT scans generally happen when cancer has already been diagnosed, and instead, ultrasounds are one of the first steps in dealing with an unknown testicular growth. In the case of this patient, although he doesn't fit the full picture for varicocele, he's asymptomatic (there could be an underlying cause though), and from my understanding, it would be a wait and observe situation.

column16:
I believe the son would be successful in his claim.

This scenario, from my understanding, constitutes promissory estoppel as the father had clear intentions of supporting his son with some generalised "requirements." The definition of promissory estoppel is: Promissory estoppel is a contract law doctrine that allows a plaintiff to recover damages, despite no actual contract, when the defendant made a promise that the plaintiff detrimentally relied upon, and the plaintiff’s reliance on that promise was reasonable..

I looked at the meaning of detrimental reliance, which is defined as a situation where one party suffers harm or incurs a loss as a result of relying on the promises or representations made by another party. The son has incurred a loss in regards to the financial support from his father, and unfortunately, the father's death caused a breach of their contract.

The biggest issue with promissory estoppel is proof, however, I think there is more than enough evidence from the letter and a potential landlord's testimony to ensure that the claim from the son would be successful.

I think this is the first time I've rejected the AI's answer so confidently. The reason for this is because the Uniform Commercial Code, which the AI referenced, actually lays out the requirements very clearly.

First, 2-308 of the Code "Absence of Specified Place for Delivery," states that unless otherwise agreed:

(a) the place for delivery of goods is the seller's place of business or if he has none his residence; but
(b) in a contract for sale of identified goods which to the knowledge of the parties at the time of contracting are in some other place, that place is the place for their delivery; and
(c) documents of title may be delivered through customary banking channels.

From the context, I think it's reasonable to believe that the plumbing parts are at the Supplier's business address, so this would become the default address for delivery under s308.

Next is understanding the terms of payment, which 2-511 of the Code, "Tender of Payment by Buyer; Payment by Check" specifies the following:

(1) Unless otherwise agreed tender of payment is a condition to the seller's duty to tender and complete any delivery.

Meaning that the seller requires payment upon completion of the delivery, rather than a "reasonable timeframe afterwards" as the AI has stated. There are a couple of other sections of the Code that reference price at the time for delivery (such as 2-305).

Finally, I found another resource that supports the answer B - "If the time for payment is not specified, then the goods must be paid for at the time and place the buyer receives the goods."

So I've gone for a very confident 100% B probability.

It took me a little while to find something that lined up specifically with this scenario, but I do believe that following my research, the prior conviction would be an exception under the hearsay rule. Rule 803 of the Federal Rules of Evidence, section 22 states:

The following are not excluded by the rule against hearsay, regardless of whether the declarant is available as a witness:

(22) Judgment of a Previous Conviction. Evidence of a final judgment of conviction if:

(A) the judgment was entered after a trial or guilty plea, but not a nolo contendere plea;

(B) the conviction was for a crime punishable by death or by imprisonment for more than a year;

(C) the evidence is admitted to prove any fact essential to the judgment; and

(D) when offered by the prosecutor in a criminal case for a purpose other than impeachment, the judgment was against the defendant.

The defendant pleaded guilty in this scenario, and the conviction is not being used as a method to demonstrate the defendant's colourful background, but rather, to showcase evidence that directly relates to the incident that occurred.

In light of this, I've gone with an 85% probability for answer B as although I might be missing something, I'm feeling somewhat confident.

This process has nothing to do with the lawyers proving the child capable.

From my understanding there is no minimum age requirement for the child providing a testimony, just that the child must be at an age where they can communicate (plus some other kind of irrelevant-to-the-question factors). In saying this, I believe Answer A is the correct answer with 100% probability.

column16:
I'm not sure if I was reading too much into some of the text, but this one was a little bit difficult for me. Firstly, under Rule 607 of the Federal Rule of Evidence, any party, including the party that called the witness, may attack the witness’s credibility. 

However, Rule 608 proceeds to state that:

Extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness’s conduct in order to attack or support the witness’s character for truthfulness. But the court may, on cross-examination, allow them to be inquired into if they are probative of the character for truthfulness or untruthfulness of:

(1) the witness; or
(2) another witness whose character the witness being cross-examined has testified about.

While this makes me believe that B is likely the correct answer, one of the more recent amendments states that Rule 608 was amended to clarify that the absolute prohibition on extrinsic evidence applies only when the sole reason for proffering that evidence is to attack or support the witness’ character for truthfulness.

So in all honesty, I felt a little bit 50/50 on this question but ultimately felt like B may be the correct answer due to the specific wording of "Admitted, but only if it's obtained from the expert witness during cross examination."

column16:
While I did not go with 100% confidence in B I do feel fairly confident that I have this one correct. My research indicated that the difference between ke'o and ke'u primarily comes down to one being vocative, and the other being discursive.

"Ke'o" is used for scenarios where repetition is request after a unsuccessful receipt or understanding from the listener. The 'Complete Guide to Lojban' indicates that "ke'o" is used in the following scenarios: 

“Roger, X!”, “I understand”; acknowledges the successful receipt of a communication from the listener, while the negative form indicates failure to receive correctly, and is usually followed by "ke'o". For example, “What did you say, X?”; a request for repetition or clarification due to unsuccessful receipt or understanding (this is a ke'o scenario).

On the other hand, "ke'u" is described in the PDF as: 

The cmavo ke'u is very similar to va'i, although ke'unai and va'inai are quite different. Both ke'u and va'i indicate that the same idea is going to be expressed using different words, but the two cmavo differ in emphasis. Using ke'u emphasizes that the content is the same - i.e. "I repeat", (the same content).

The two answers had me a little bit conflicted until I thought of an analogy. Basically, my thought process is that I needed to confirm the exceptions to the hearsay rule, in which I do believe this situation would fall under the exception of an excited utterance.

This does appear to be a question that relates to hip dysplasia in babies. So, while babies who have a hip pop or hip click can be diagnosed with hip dysplasia, not all babies with a hip pop have a problem with their hips. The specific sentence I found regarding this was "When an infant has a “hip click” it does not mean that a baby has hip dysplasia. While some infants that have a hip click will be diagnosed with hip dysplasia, there are babies with hip clicks that have normal hips."

An ultrasound is the appropriate approach in diagnosing hip dysplasia in babies as their hips are apparently mostly cartilage. However, I feel that with the low-risk scenario and the baby being 3 weeks old, an ultrasound wouldn't be the doctor's first answer to a hip pop. To me, I'd imagine a doctor reassuring the mother "while the popping could be a sign of dysplasia, let's keep an eye on it for the next appointment". I also found a graph that state babies <4 weeks should wait until 4 weeks for an ultrasound if there are any symptoms.

This was a difficult scenario because I felt as though there wasn't a whole lot of supporting information for either answer. However, I found myself focusing more so on the consideration aspect of the contract, over the release in writing.

While it's ideal that a modification to a contract should be in writing, I found two cases that deal with the variation of a contract verbally, when the written contract contains a clause requiring any variations to be in writing:

Son-Shine Grading, Inc. v. ADC Const. Co., 68 N.C. App. 417, 315 S.E.2d 346 (1984) which found that a  verbal agreement between superintendents for contractor and subcontractor sufficient to amend subcontract despite clause prohibiting verbal amendments);

Charles T. Driscoll Masonry Restoration Co., Inc. v. Cty. of Ulster, 40 A.D.3d 1289, 1291–92, 836 N.Y.S.2d 362, 365–66 (2007) which found that the contractor obtaining written change orders during the time in dispute showed the parties did not waive formal requirements of changes clause.

In light of the above and my findings on the pre-existing duty doctrine, I believe that the following applies to this scenario: if a party to a contract does what they are already obligated to do in exchange for a modification of the contract, the modification will be voidable. I think this may be applicable in some way, but I felt as though it would take far more time to be more confident, hence the 45/55 probability.

The symptoms of the patient are not super abnormal, only some irregularities. 

I found that erythromycin can be used for a multitude of reasons, one being if a patient has intestinal amebiasis, which is an intestinal illness caused by a microscopic parasite called Entamoeba histolytica. However, everything else pointed towards the appropriateness of a nasogastric tube decompression.

It appeared over and over in my research that nasogastric tube (NGT) decompression is ideal for a distended and tympanitic bowel, as it relieves the patient of the distention pain and helps small bowel obstructions resolve over the course of a few days. If it's not resolved, that is when other methods are looked into.

I don't think that the erythromycin is of any relevant use in this scenario, except for the fact that the patient was homeless, and the bacteria that erythromycin treats is a bacteria that is transferred via fecal matter. All in all, I think B is definitely the correct answer in this situation.

column16: The reason I believe is that the employee will prevail is because the doctrine of promissory estoppel applies here because all the requirements are being fulfilled. The company did not have any retirement plans for at will employees and only after the conversation with the company's president they offered this specific employee a pension plan. The employee then acted on this and took a retirement along with the purchases . I do also believe that there is a breach of contract but from what I've researched in the US, private pensions are generally required to pay insurance premiums to the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation to insure their pension benefits. The PBGC is a government chartered entity that protects pension benefits even if your company goes bankrupt or there are no assets left in the pension https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pension_Benefit_Guaranty_Corporation. Furthermore pensions are voluntary for companies and they can end the schemes. Considering they have a recession and proof that current salaries are being impacted aswell, they can justify this. This makes me believe while indeed there may have been a breach of contract they courts might try to find a middle ground or something based solely on this. However with the doctrine of promissory estoppel they employee will most likely prevail.

column16: I searched up on rule 404 and followed the guidelines of AI . According to rule 404 "Evidence of a person’s character or character trait is not admissible to prove that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character or trait" which is why I'm certain that option A is invalid since you cannot quote a previous fraud. On further research I was able to find Rule 404(b)(2) which provides exceptions where the evidence is offered for purposes other than to prove character. The rule provides nine permitted non-character uses for introducing crimes or prior bad acts: motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, absence of mistake and lack of accident. I believe  Rule 404(b)(2) applies here and the thus option B is correct. I was went through some cases UNITED STATES v. SCALI (2020) and UNITED STATES OF AMERICA v. ELSAYED KAZAM SAFIEDINE

column16: After reading through 18 U.S. Code § 3509 - Child victims’ and child witnesses’ rights and multiple case laws. I was able to understand that all children regardless of age can present as witness however due to some factors the judge may decide to conduct a competence test on a case to case basis. It states "A competency examination regarding a child may be conducted only if the court determines, on the record, that compelling reasons exist. A child’s age alone is not a compelling reason" . Looking at this specific case, the child saw their parent getting murdered and were also a victim themself. This is compelling reason to believe that the child may be suffering from trauma. This is why its best to present compelling evidence that convinces the presiding judge of the juvenile witness's capacity to provide a reliable testimony

column16: I first looked up at the symptoms of subclavian steal syndrome and found them to closely match the description of the patients symptoms. The most evident symptom here was the bruit heard above patient's left clavicle. Subclavian steal syndrome is most likely to occur in people who are chronic smokers and usually the left side is affected. At this point I was certain that this is a case of subclavian steal syndrome however I double checked to see if any other disease could exhibit similar symptoms. Subclavian Artery Stenosis was a probability but this was ruled out as the patient exhibited dizziness and vertigo. Thus now I was confident that this is subclavian steal syndrome in which systolic blood pressure measurements in the right and left arms is not equal and management of this disease requires a stent/angioplasty

I first looked up the definitions of each "declaration against interest" and "statement made by a co-conspirator" and reading a few case laws. Both options fall under exceptions to the hearsay rule thus have alot of conditions to fulfil. I was able to find that for it to be classified as a statement made by a co-conspirator there must sufficient evidence to demonstrate existence of the conspiracy already. Therefore in this case this ruling seems unlikely since the insurance company is using this statement to prove conspiracy rather than using this statement as further proof of an already ongoing conspiracy trial. Option A seems more likely since the conditions 1) the declarant must be unavailable as a witness and
 2) the party offering the statements must prove that the statements would harm the declarant’s legal claims against someone or aid in legal claims against themselves are fulfilled. By telling this statement to his wife, the person removes any chance of his wife getting money from the defendant/insurance. Therefore this is against the interest

I started by looking into the hearsay rule and what exceptions are there in the law which make hearsay admissible. Since the passenger did not directly see the driver drink, this is hearsay information. The fact that this could be classified under the "against declarant's interest" exception is not true since law does not require passengers to be sober. Then I looked over what makes a statement/testimony relevant and in this case the statement is relevant since a) there is the tendency to make a fact more or less probable than it would be without the evidence; and (b) the fact is of consequence in determining the action.

Thus option A is correct

A statement is not hearsay if the statement is offered against a party and is (E) a statement by a co-conspirator of a party during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy. Therefore this may be submitted as evidence albeit it may not be enough

column16: After doing research, I initially felt like the AI's answer was actually the best choice. However, certain factors were left unanswered and seemed to go against the AI's reasoning. First, the fact that the mass remained the same after laying down. Research suggested that a varicoceles should “reduce” or decrease in fullness when a patient is lying down since the gravity no longer fills the pampiniform plexus of veins. Second, although it may rarely occur, a right-sided varicocele could be indicative of a more serious underlying problem. Especially given that the mass did not reduce in size after being in the supine position. Further research indicated that due to its rarity in occurrence and presenting symptoms, a more definitive test should be undertaken, in the form of an ultrasound or a CT scan. This is mainly to rule out any serious cases such as the presence of a tumor or an abdominal blood vessel blockage.

column16:
Research reveals the Molineux Rule, that states that "Evidence of crimes, wrongs, or other acts committed by a person is not admissible to prove that the person acted in conformity therewith on a particular occasion or had a propensity to engage in a wrongful act or acts. This evidence may be admissible when it is more probative than prejudicial to prove, for
example: motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, common scheme or plan, knowledge, identity, absence of mistake or accident, or conduct that is inextricably interwoven with the charged acts." This just further supports the AI assistant's explanation of how absence of mistake or accident makes the evidence admissible.

column16: After researching, I have found that oral modifications to a written contract can be enforceable (in the absence of a no or modification clause) as long as they can prove the existence of a consideration. A "consideration is a promise, performance, or forbearance bargained by a promisor in exchange for their promise. Consideration is the main element of a contract. Without consideration by both parties, a contract cannot be enforceable." The contract in question does not seem to clearly meet the Statute of Fraud requirements because it is not sale or transfer of land or clearly stated that the project cannot be completed within one year. There is however the existence of Good faith modification: "A modified contract is a kind of new agreement, which changes parties’ obligations and then requires new consideration. But contract modification made in good faith under UCC is enforceable even without consideration." I also found that "nonperformance can also discharge contractual obligations. Not every instance of nonperformance results in a breach of contract. Parties can agree to discharge a contractual obligation by terms in the contracts, mutual rescission, waiver, novation accord and satisfaction, and general release." All of these suggest that the verbal modification to the contract doesn't have to be in writing and that release from contractual obligation is enforceable with or without the presence of a consideration.

column16:
After doing some digging, I found out that the dying declaration exception to hearsay is admissible in court. The declarant's previous statement falls under the "Statement Under the Belief of Imminent Death. In a prosecution for homicide or in a civil case, a statement that the declarant, while believing the declarant’s death to be imminent, made about its cause or circumstances." Unfortunately, I couldn't find a clear support as to whether the nurse's statement and the medical intern's affidavit are admissible. There is however evidence online suggesting that it may be deemed reliable if it is effective - "an effective medical affidavit included clear, concise, and corroborative accounts of the applicant’s story from a diagnostic perspective, as well as descriptions that reinforce their credibility." Furthermore, 
an online source cited that "the exact limitations on the admissibility of hearsay at a preliminary hearing are still subject to ongoing litigation." I feel that the hearsay exception in this case was what gave me more confidence in supporting my initial answer.

column16: Online research has show that "Chronic leg ulcers are commonly due to poor drainage of blood from the legs (venous insufficiency) and/or poor blood supply to the legs (peripheral vascular disease)." In addition, Vascular pathology is ideally confirmed by Doppler ultrasound (DUS) or other non‐invasive means of visualizing arterial blood flow obstruction. Differential diagnosis of leg ulcers complicated by PAD is typically confirmed by an ABI value <0.9. I also discovered that a Duplex ultrasound (DUS) is an excellent modality but Multidetector CT angiography (CTA) is often the next step in the diagnostic algorithm. Finally, the common first line of treatment for PAD, if proven to be non-life threatening are lifestyle changes, foot care, and medications such as antiplatelet agents, pain meds, cholesterol lower- meds, high blood pressure meds, and anti-coagulants.

column16:
By definition, Undue influence occurs when an individual is able to persuade another's decisions due to the relationship between the two parties. Often, one of the parties is in a position of power over the other due to elevated status, higher education, or emotional ties. The more powerful individual uses this advantage to coerce the other individual into making decisions that might not be in their long-term best interest.
I found online sources differentiating coercion as a separate criminal offence, and that undue influence doesn't have to technically be coercive in nature but more of taking advantage of one's superiority to another. Also, I couldn't find a clear definition of sufficiency of consideration as a grounds to invalidate a contract, since both parties agree to the value, regardless of whether it be fair or equal, before entering an agreement. The relationship between the mother and daughter, and how the latter influenced her mother's decision by threatening to cease emotional support is a clear example of undue influence. Finally, an online source says that undue influence is a legal concept that renders the contract voidable if proven.

column16: After doing a bit of research, I have found sources proving that the evidence in this case would not be considered hearsay. Although if it would be admissible as hearsay, a possible reason would be the "matter of record" exception, which states that "Evidence provided that is a matter record is exempt from being declared Hearsay and is therefore admissible. This includes any official or legal documents such as: Promissory notes, Birth certificates, Prior court rulings, Tax returns, Contracts." I have also found that Judges usually consider evidence of prior convictions for the same or a similar crime (as the one the defendant now faces) very prejudicial. However, in this situation, it wasn't being used for the same case rather as evidence of intoxication for a civil case. Furthermore, I found a previous legal precedent with a slight similarity where the case involves "a Florida court affirmed that evidence of a defendant’s prior conviction was relevant and, therefore, admissible in a matter in which it upheld the defendant’s conviction."

The situation in which the two parties agreed meet these requirements. However, the reason why the neighbor would not succeed is for the reason that the woman had "Lack of Capacity." An online source states that "having a contractual capacity means fully understanding the terms and conditions, the consequences of signing the contract, and having the ability to fulfill the contractual obligations without any legal or practical barriers." Furthermore, "for declaring the contract voidable, intoxication must be severe and the intoxicated party should argue for voidance once returning to “normal” consciousness and with the belief that the contract was signed mistakenly." Also, "when assessing whether the intoxication can negate contractual capacity, the court will look at the severity of the intoxication and the counterparty's knowledge of this intoxication." The key note is the fact that the neighbor clearly knew the fact that the old lady was under medication and that the car would have a fair market value way higher than the price agreed upon.

Your blood pressure in one arm could be at least 15 millimeters of mercury (mmHg) higher than the other." The varying strength in pulses in both arms would surely result to unequal blood pressure readings, which eliminates the possibility of answer A being correct. Further digging reveals that the physical exams needed to confirm subclavian steal syndrome may reveal the same signs mentioned in the question. Although in most cases, subclavian steal syndrome can be asymptomatic and would not warrant any further treatment, the patient in this case presents signs that require immediate intervention. Finally, another site mentions, "If you have symptoms, subclavian steal syndrome treatment may mean surgery to improve blood flow in your subclavian artery." This may mean the insertion of a stent - a small tube typically made of metal or plastic mesh, a stent keeps your coronary arteries open and reduces your risk for heart attack.

column16: Firstly, the two parties agreed and signed a contract with a specific date for the delivery. An online source says that a party's silence to an undisclosed payment term in a contract suggests that, under UCC regulations, they agree to paying a "reasonable price." All of the rules are covered under a UCC doctrine which states, "The third UCC doctrine is the UCC’s “gap filler” rules. The traditional law of contracts requires that the parties to a contract have mutual assent to the key elements of the bargain.[6] Because the UCC’s policy encourages enforceability and the ability to contract quickly and reliably, the UCC allows contracts to become enforceable even without agreement on all important terms. For example, the parties may not know the price, date of delivery, or payment terms. When certain terms are left out of a contract, Article 2 provides “gap filler” terms that are used to determine each party’s responsibilities under the contract.[7] For example, when the place of delivery is not specified in the contract, then the gap filler states that the seller’s place of business will be the default rule.[8] If the time for payment is not specified, then the goods must be paid for at the time and place the buyer receives the goods.[9] Even if the parties to a completed agreement fail to reference something so fundamental as the price, the contract is enforceable at a “reasonable price.” If a party does not want to rely on a gap filler provision of Article 2, then he can include specific requirements in the contract."

column16:
Research indicates that "the Supreme Court has also held that a party can impeach a witness by cross-examining them about specific instances of conduct that show their lack of credibility, as long as the questions are related to the witness's character for truthfulness." Furthermore, another online source states that "Specific Instances of Conduct - Except for a criminal conviction under Rule 609, extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness’s conduct in order to attack or support the witness’s character for truthfulness. But the court may, on cross-examination, allow them to be inquired into if they are probative of the character for truthfulness or untruthfulness of:
(1) the witness." These further support the AI's explanation since the witness' character may be cross-examined to question his/her truthfulness. I found no clear rule regarding inappropriate character evidence for a witness being cross-examined. Unfortunately, I couldn't find any existing records of a similar case involving such a situation.

column16:
This was a little confusing, because of how both answers seem to make a point. After a bit of research, both the declaration against interest and statement made by a co-conspirator seem to apply. However, like I previously mentioned, the dying man's statement seems to point more towards his crime to start a fire and not admit his involvement to the conspiracy. The wife's testimony and the dead man's statement meet the three criteria for a declaration against interest: 
"In order for a statement to be considered a declaration against interest, it must meet certain requirements. First, the person who made the statement must not be available to testify in court. Second, the statement must be harmful to the person who made it or helpful to the other party in the case. Lastly, in a criminal case, there must be other evidence that makes the statement more trustworthy."

I also found an online source stating that cases where statements were made by a co-conspirator usually involve an undercover police and the coconspirator is fully aware of the act during his or her admission of involvement.

If we consider the statement made by a co-conspirator to be correct, it would require more proof of the existence of the conspiracy and his conscious involvement in the act.

column16:
I initially agreed to the AI's answer, but further research pulled up some surprising details. An online source states: "A majority of states that allow the admission of pre-Miranda silence as evidence of guilt do so as an extension of Fletcher v. Weir, 455 U.S. 603, 607 (1982) (holding that post-arrest, pre-Miranda silence can be used to impeach a testifying defendant). See, e.g., State v. Brown, 517 A.2d 831, 835–36 (N.H. 1986). Most states that exclude pre-Miranda silence do so because their state constitutions require it." Another website points out that "The Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Eleventh Circuit Courts have all
taken the position that the prosecution’s use of a defendant’s post-arrest pre-Miranda silence as substantive evidence of guilt does not violate Fifth Amendment protections against self-incrimination." Another source says "Silence cannot be used against defendants in court. However, there is a term known as “pre-Miranda” silence, which occurs when a suspect has not be read his or her Miranda Rights and still remains silent. In that case, silence can be seen as unusual and suspect." These resources seem to support the fact that accused A's admittance to the crime and mention of accused B's role, without B's objection, could be admissible as evidence in court. It was still vague and confusing but this has led me to change my answer eventually.

column16: Research says that in a US contract law, there must be consideration for the contract to be enforceable. In the case of a contest, the performance and the offer of a prize would amount to consideration. One important note an online source makes is "once the offeree has started the performance, the offeror cannot back out of the contract and must fulfill their promise, even if the offeree has not completed the act yet. However, if the offeree has not started performing, the offeror can revoke the offer at any time." Additionally, another site mentions that "acceptance of a unilateral contract happens when the offeree performs their part of the contract. It's not enough for the offeree to begin to perform—the offeree must complete the required performance." In the question, the customer did fulfill their end of the contract by completing the required performance. One website cites a somewhat similar case where "Robertson v. United States, 343 U.S. 711, 72 S. Ct. 994, 96 L. Ed. 1237 (1952) (The acceptance by the contestants of the offer tendered by the sponsor of the contest creates an enforceable contract.)" Furthermore, I couldn't find any sources that might suggest that the part where the bank says "they may discontinue the promotion at any moment" to serve as a termination for convenience clause. It's for these reasons that I believe answer B is more correct.

column16: One website explains that "Although a document must be signed by each party to be considered legally binding, the mere presence of signatures does not guarantee that an agreement is enforceable in court. To be considered a legally binding contract or document, three critical elements must also be present: Subject, Consideration, and Capacity." In the question, the subject is the proposed lease agreement which is contained in the uncle and nephew's correspondence, the consideration is the monetary value proposed, and the capacity is their mental and legal capacity to come to an agreement. Another source indicates that "Correspondence alone may establish a contract enforceable under the Statute of Frauds. We typically think of a contract as one more or less "formal" document signed by all the parties to the agreement, but the Statutes of Frauds do not require all the contract terms to be set out in one document.  North Carolina courts have held that a series of emails and letters between two parties regarding negotiating the purchase of land can, when taken as a whole, create a written contract under the applicable Statute of Frauds.  As long as the correspondence is from a person authorized to enter into the contract and contains a meeting of the minds and all the material provisions of the deal (offer and acceptance), a legally-enforceable contract may be created without either party signing one document containing all those terms." Although there it is unclear whether the uncle confirms his receipt of the nephew's acceptance, the uncle's phone confirmation of the landlord's agreement supports his desire to continue with the proposition. If the agreement is indeed legally binding, given the details mentioned, then the uncle cannot just simply relinquish the agreement on a whim.

column16:
An online resource points out that "Under the Youth Justice and Criminal Evidence Act 1999, section 53 (1) clearly states that at every stage in criminal proceedings all individuals are (whatever their age) competent to give evidence. A child’s competency depends on their understanding and not their age." To be able to check a child witness' competence, A voir dire examination is usually held. The trial judge has substantial discretion regarding the conduct of this examination. The burden of proof rests on the party challenging the child's capacity to testify. This means that, like answer B mentioned, it is the responsibility of the prosecuting attorney to present proof that the child witness is indeed competent. In addition, I found an online document regarding a somewhat similar case In 1895 the United States Supreme Court established the policy followed by most of the state courts thereafter. In Wheeler v. United States" it was held that a five and one-half year old child was competent
to testify in a criminal trial for murder. In this case, it was the presiding judge's discretion to assess the competency of the child witness.

I did note that if the scenario had taken place at some point in the past, before the law changed on when a unilateral contract offer can be revoked, then B would have been incorrect. (Note: I'm sorry, I started the timer a few seconds too late!)

My first goal was to confirm the definitions that the AI assigned to 'tavla' and 'casnu' were correct. I was able to confirm this quite quickly via some reputable Lojban online resources.

Rather than take the AI's word for it that 'casnu' would be more correct, my next step was to confirm whether Lojban has room for nuance. I don't think I had even managed to search for that yet before stumbling upon an assertion by a speaker in r/Lojban that the language leaves no room for ambiguity. I then confirmed this assertion via another trustworthy resource. 

Given that a goal of this constructed language is to eliminate ambiguity, it therefore makes sense that if the language contains different words for "talk" and "discuss", they would not be used interchangeably. If this was indeed a discussion that the sentence referred to, then the word for 'discuss' would certainly be used.

English is of course a more nuanced language, but considering the sentiment that what they had "talked about" was very important to them, this suggests a discussion, as opposed to a less purposeful "talk" (i.e. 'small talk'), which I gather 'tavla' would imply.

Since I had plenty of time remaining, I did some other research to confirm the definitions were correct. Once I had done this, I was certain that short of asking an actual Lojban speaker about this directly, I had exhausted all channels of research, so I finished early.

I assigned 10/90 probability rather than 0/100 because although I'm confident that this is the correct answer, I don't believe there is a way to 100% confirm this via online research (aside from asking a Lojban speaker!).

column16:
I think the AI is incorrect. I think it has gotten mixed up between the two statements (by security guard and director), as I did at first when I read through the question and its reasoning.

The retail store is on trial here (and so is the party being represented); when the security guard made his statement during his own criminal proceedings, he was no longer an employee of the store. The AI says that the statement is admissible because he was an employee at the time he was given the instructions by the director. But the exception states that he had to be been an employee at the time he made his OWN statement, not when the director made his 'statement' to the employee.

At first, I did some research on exceptions to the hearsay rule, and to determine what was meant by 'party's agent'. I was confused throughout the first chunk of research as I was trying to prove the AI correct, and it didn't make sense.

Finally, it clicked that the AI had the statements mixed up, and I was able to confirm that while yes, what it said about Rule 801(d)(D) is correct, it would not apply in this case because the security guard was not an employee at the time of making the (transcripted) testimony in question.

My research confirmed the rules around the admissibility of hearsay, but it was mostly by re-reading, and carefully thinking through the question and AI response, that I arrived at my answer. The initial research to define certain terminology helped me to understand and consider this more clearly.

I settled on 30/70 because while my understanding of the matter has me convinced, I have no legal background, and I didn't understand some of the terminology before my 20 mins of research. My answer mostly hinges on my own understanding, which might be inaccurate. I'd expect a highly-trained AI to produce a better answer than myself here. 

(If I am correct, I'm going to feel very clever!)

column16:
I firstly researched US contract law and gifts, since my initial hunch had been that this was the correct answer (albeit based on no actual knowledge). 

In the course of this research, I came across the concept of Promissory Estoppel. This would certainly validate the second point in the AI's response – the part that I had had my doubts about. 

I assumed the first point in the AI's response was correct, that the formal, signed decree would constitute a contract. And the 'action' on the part of the executive to fulfil his part of the contract would be the act of retirement, which he did.

But I noted that he was filing the lawsuit under 'breach of contract'. Without having any knowledge of law, I spent most of the rest of my research time aiming to clarify whether Promissory Estoppel can be applied in a breach of contract lawsuit, or whether this would be a separate lawsuit/argument. After all, some of the (reliable) resources suggested that Promissory Estoppel applies when a contract is not present, i.e. it was 'just' a promise.

I note that I then got so caught up in this that I didn't do any research on whether financial difficulties would absolve the company from its contractual obligations. So I'm taking the AI on its word for this point!

My final 75:25 probability is based on the fact that Promissory Estoppel did appear in multiple resources as part of a larger "contract law" or "breach of contract" section. And some text suggested that it would apply as an exception, although I confess I didn't 100% understand the explanations.

So, while I didn't conclusively satisfy myself that Promissory Estoppel can be applied alongside the other argument points given by the AI in a breach of contract lawsuit, even if a contract was present, I am going on the assumption that this is the case. In which case, as the multiple-choice 'A' response relies on this fact (rather than the other points made by the AI), the AI would be correct.

column16:
(Note: I had to re-do the Q5 video as scre.io failed to record anything – which I only discovered after my research.)

At first, I decided to check out what some reliable sources said about undue influence. The definition seemed to fit the AI's description, but there was emphasis on how this needed to be proved, and how that could be difficult. Although we know from the description that undue influence DID happen, I needed to be sure that the son could prove it. 

My next searches showed that to prove undue influence, one must demonstrate that the accused received a substantial benefit (they did), and that they had a confidential relationship with the victim (they did). According to https://www.upchurchlaw.com/blog/2022/may/how-to-prove-undue-influence/, the 'signs' of undue influence were also met (surprisingly large amount left to individual with no explanation, the victim was vulnerable, and they were dependent on the accused, albeit for company not for care).

At that point I felt more convinced of the 'undue influence' argument, but now needed to research 'insufficient consideration'.

The resources I found were murky on the subject; they stated that normally, courts would not care about assessing fair monetary value of the exchange if the contract had been agreed by both parties. 

One website used the alternative term "inadequate consideration", so I researched this, on the assumption it was the same thing. The website I consulted suggested that the value consideration would need to be "grossly inadequate to shock the conscience”, i.e. extreme, in order to void the contract. I continued to research insufficient consideration plus the keyword "extreme" until my time was up.

At the end of my research, I felt I could not conclusively determine which answer was correct, as it would probably come down to whether undue influence could be proved, vs. whether paying $100k for a $250k house is considered extremely unfair.

As I know from the description that undue influence did happen, and that the conditions for proving it appear to be met (as far as my research showed), I felt this was the more likely answer. If the house had been sold for a ridiculous amount such as $1 or even $10k, I'd consider this to be extreme, but in a sale between family members, I didn't think $100k was much of a stretch. Hence, my 70/30 answer.

At first I looked up English translations of the two Lojban words in question, since they comprised the only difference between responses. They seemed to confirm the AI's definitions, but I still wasn't sure which one would apply.

I then researched Hajj, as while I had some idea of what the event consisted of, I wanted to confirm the specifics. I found that Hajj refers to a pilgrimage that takes place WITHIN Mecca (moving through Mecca).

Still, I felt that going by the English use of "in", either translation could apply.

I then searched various Lojban resources for examples of both words in use. One translated phrase that I found on r/lojban helped:

"xu ro plise pe ne'i le lanka cu xunre — go'i na'i. Are all the apples in the basket red ?"

Ne'i was used here, and we could easily replace "basket" with "Mecca" here. So I thought perhaps ne'i is the correct term to use when referring to a place.

However, other translated phrases found via the Glosbe dictionary confused me further. ("These cameras are made in Japan. – loi vi kacma cu se zbasu bu'u lo pongu'e" – one could also replace "Japan" with "Mecca" here.)

I then found a website that, although it didn't cover "ne'i", it defined "bu'u" as follows:

bu'u ma	– Where? – (literally) "at what"

I felt this reinforced the idea I had already gleaned from the AI's explanation, that "bu'u" would translate more to "at Mecca" while "ne'i" would more correctly translate to "in Mecca".

As the original English phrase used "in Mecca" (and I ran out of time trying to find helpful examples, after realising I'd never understand Lojban grammar quickly), I decided that B was more likely correct. However, I hadn't conclusively proved this, and I feel my reasoning is a little flimsy, so I stuck with the 40/60 probability.

column16:
(Note: I assigned 0 to option A, but the form will only accept numbers 1-100.)

Firstly, I decided to research the medical terms that I did not understand. I checked out each term (and sometimes an accompanying image) on reputable medical websites (and on Wikipedia at one point, though I just clicked through to see the image).

I also considered the parts of the explanation that I did already understand. The patient's abdomen was distended. He had also been drinking alcohol. We all need to pee after a few beers! The AI stated that the bladder dome is susceptible to injury in high-energy trauma, especially when the bladder is full. Given all this, I think it's likely that the patient's bladder was full.

I also note that the patient was restrained (wearing a seat belt) while driving. Having experienced wearing a seat belt with a full bladder, I know that even in normal circumstances, the bottom part of the seatbelt can exert uncomfortable pressure over the bladder. In a high-speed collision, an injury here does seem likely. The fact that my research backed this up, and noted that the bladder dome is the weakest part of the bladder, strengthens the argument.

My research confirmed that the bladder dome does sit near the peritoneum (much nearer to it than the male urethra does). When I translated the medical language to learn that the CT scan showed that fluid was actively leaking from somewhere into the peritoneum, I agreed with the AI that it was more likely to have come via a breach in the bladder dome. (And there was no option for another intra-pelvic injury to have been the cause.)

I was feeling quite certain that the AI was right at this point, so I decided to research the opposite argument for the urethra. I found that a common symptom of urethral injury in males is blood at the meatus – which the patient did not have. I found that another cause of urethra injury in males is a high-riding prostate, but it was stated that the patient's prostate was normal.

I also found that gross hematuria – blood in the urine – can also happen with a bladder dome injury.

In summary, once I had 'translated' the medical language into something more understandable to me, and did some research on symptoms and causes of the two types of injury in question, I was completely confident that the AI was correct. At the point where I felt that no more research would help either way, I set my probability at 0/100 and stopped my research early.

column11: The AI suggested a specific condition that might be the cause. So, assuming the AI was correct about this being a potential symptom of DDH, I thought it was likely correct.
column14: After my research: A (Reassure the mother): 10%; B (Arrange an ultrasound of the hip): 90%
column16:
I immediately went to research the condition mentioned, DDH. On the first website (NHS, so trustworthy), it mentioned risk factors for this condition. The baby is female, and being female is a risk factor, but the baby did not seem to meet the other risk factors, as the pregnancy was unremarkable (amniotic fluid not low), delivery was smooth (not breech) and they were not the firstborn (mother was G3P2 – I had to look that up).

The NHS website also suggested that a scan should take place at 4-6 weeks of age, but this baby is only 3 weeks old.

So I was not yet convinced.

I then decided to check what other credible websites said about when the baby should receive a scan. Some suggested that hip instability often corrects itself by 2-3 weeks of age, which seemed a likely reason for waiting on a scan. Later on, another website (NIH) suggested that a scan isn't reliable until the fourth week of life (day 22 and beyond). At first I thought this suggested the baby shouldn't be scanned, but then realised if it's 3 weeks old, that would put it at 21 days. (There also seemed to be disagreement online on when was the optimal time for a scan.)

I also thought about wait times for getting an ultrasound scan. It's not clear where this situation is taking place, and in any case it would be hard to predict. But assuming a wait time of a week or so, the baby would then be safely within the NHS' recommended 4-6 week range. The NHS website even mentioned that a baby's hip may stabilise on its own before the scan is due, but that it should still be checked out anyway.

So, I concluded that it's not too early to order a scan.

I did still wonder whether the scan would be considered 'overkill' considering the baby's relatively low risk factors. But the NHS Scotland clinical guidelines suggested that 75% of DDH cases are females, and so other risk factors are poor predictors. A radiology website confirmed there are no adverse effects of an infant receiving an ultrasound scan. So, probably not overkill.

In the meantime, I had also confirmed that a hip popping sound is a potential sign of DDH. It might also simply indicate a 'clicky hip', but it's recommended to get a scan if the medical examiner is not sure of the cause. This isn't mentioned in the original description, but I'd personally err on the side of caution if unsure.

At the end of my research period, I was very certain that the AI was correct – the next step is to order an ultrasound scan. Due to some slight uncertainty over low risk factors, potential for 'clicky hip' and scan timing vs the child's age, I set my probability at 10/90.

column16:
Since use of za'a vs ga'a was the only difference between the two responses, I immediately went to look up their definitions.

I went with ga'a first, since the AI suggested it was correct. It was tricky to find a clear definition regarding perspective; the first website I checked suggested it was indeed about witnessing/observing, but from whose perspective (reader or listener) it wasn't clear.

I then looked up za'a, and found that a couple of Lojban dictionary websites defined it as "I observe." I checked the definition of an 'evidential' in Lojban, as za'a was described as being an evidential. I found that evidential refers to the type of particle that it is, so that didn't affect my understanding of it.

I also then found on Lojban.org that "A bridi marked by za'a is based on perception or direct observation by the speaker." 

From previous research (on an earlier question) I know that Lojban is a logical language that aims to eliminate ambiguity. Therefore, I don't believe that a particle meant to indicate an action (seeing the snake) on the speaker's part would be used to indicate an action on the listener's part. 

So this seemed to eliminate (A) as a possibility.

I had plenty of time left, so I continued my research to get to the bottom of the definition of ga'a.

I checked the definition of zgana after finding that ga'a is a preposition from this word, but unfortunately it turned out that za'a is also a preposition from zgana, so this didn't help.

I then found a further ga'a definition on Lojban.org that seemed to place ga'a as more passive, referring to "what is being observed". However this seems to be when a noun is placed directly after it, which I don't believe is the case in the provided sentence.

Regardless, if ga'a refers to what is being observed "as you can see" and za'a refers more to the observer, ga'a would be more correct. I was also confident that I had eliminated za'a as a possibility. I ended my research early.

My final probability of 1/99 indicates that I am certain I eliminated A as a possible answer. However, I wasn't able to confirm the AI's exact definition of ga'a as "used to indicate that the listener has directly observed something".
