As mentioned, I already leaned towards B as the correct answer. I previously worked closely with salespeople at a software company. From experience, I couldn't fathom why A would be correct – in the question it does not state that the salesperson continued to support the client after his termination, and it does state that another salesperson was assigned to the account. So, that salesperson would be doing the follow-up support. Even if no-one had been reassigned to the account as yet, a terminated employee would never be allowed to conduct follow-up support with a client. And in any case, the follow-up support is costing the manufacturer money, not the client. So there's no reason it should have any bearing on why the salesperson should get his commission.

Proving that A was incorrect, or that B was correct, was difficult, however.

Firstly, I looked up general reasons as to why an employment contract might become invalid, to get some ideas for further research. One website mentioned contracts might become invalid if they fail to adhere to business law in general. So, I checked US law in general on withholding sales commissions.

I found that in this case, state law can overrule employment contract terms regarding commission, but not federal law. In this case, I concluded that state law was not applicable, because the question didn't mention the state in which the company/salesperson was based, and in any case, the reasoning in (A) for the employee prevailing didn't involve state law.

I then turned to the reasoning in (A) and tried researching support clauses in contracts, follow up support, etc, but couldn't find anything relevant. Looking for further 'clues' in the question, I briefly checked whether any changes to the law regarding sales commissions had been enacted in 2010 or 2011, but nothing came up (I didn't spend much time on this though).

I then tried to look up federal regulations regarding compensation and commission, but didn't have much luck with that. 

Finally, I went back to my earlier search on withholding sales commission, and found a website that specifically discussed the withholding of commission after a termination. It reiterated that it would be state law that would overrule any terms in the employment contract. It also mentioned that an agreement is considered stronger in writing (as the contract was), and it even mentioned that some companies may stipulate that commission is only earned when the invoice is generated, which matches our situation exactly.

At the end of my research, I felt very strongly that (B) was the correct response. (A) just didn't seem to make any sense, and it seemed that if the client prevailed, it would be down to state law, not another reason. 

But, I couldn't prove it – not even close. Hence my final 25/75 probability.

column16:
This one felt a bit "chicken and egg". Was the contract voidable – or was there a contract in the first place? It seemed that, if the contract was voidable due to incapacity, the correct answer would be 'whichever comes first'.

I researched oral contracts initially, to see whether they are legally binding in the US. Yes, they generally are, but it's difficult to prove. So, (A) was still possibly correct.

I noted that the neighbour wanted to buy the car for business purposes. I ran a search on whether oral contracts can be applied when one party is a business, but no results seemed to jump out at me either way.

Then, I decided to check out the reasoning behind (B). Would incapacity void a contract?

According to LII, yes, a contract with someone deemed incompetent is voidable unless the contract involves a person who has legal guardianship of them. 

I then found that according to Investopedia, "a contract may be void if it is found that one of the parties was incapable of fully understanding its implications." But here, I learned there is a difference between "void" and "voidable". I read up on the differences, but "voidable" seemed to apply here as much as "void" did. The difference being, that despite the contract being unfair, if it's voidable, it can still go ahead if both parties are willing. In this case, it wouldn't change the outcome for the neighbour.

I briefly wondered (off-screen) whether by suing for breach of contract, that was acknowledgement of there being a contract. But then I realised it would only be by acknowledgement by the plaintiff, so that wasn't relevant.

I then looked up wither a voidable contract can be oral – yes, it can.

At this point, I came across the Statute of Frauds, but found that it doesn't apply to invalidate the oral contract in this case, as the proposed sale was for less than $500.

I finally thought it over again, and concluded that capacity seems to come 'first' in this 'chicken and egg' scenario. If the neighbour was incapacitated – which she was – there couldn't even be an ORAL contract to start with, let alone any contract. So there'd be no oral contract to invalidate (because it wasn't written down), making (B) the more likely answer.

My final probabilities of 25/75 reflect that both (A) and (B) still seem like valid reasons to invalidate the contract, as the AI also seems to imply. But (B) seems to apply before (A) could be considered – in my head at least. I didn't prove this.

Firstly, I needed to understand the medical terminology being used.

I looked up Acute Otitis Media, and found that it's an infection of the middle ear. I then looked up the middle ear, mostly to get a visual of the area in question.

Then I looked up "superior displacement of the ear", which means the ear is protruding. Otitis was mentioned in the results here, but so was Mastoiditis, which the AI mentioned. Mastoiditis can indeed be a complication of Otitis, as the AI claimed.

According to the NIH web page I consulted, "if the initial AOM [acute otitis media] was treated with antibiotics,  there may be an interval of improvement followed by an abrupt worsening of symptoms" – this is just as described in the question. This website also mentioned that in Mastoiditis, the ear will protrude.

I then checked the other symptoms mentioned in the question and by the AI. I confirmed the child did have a fever, but this can be present in both Otitis and Mastoiditis. I then confirmed the meaning of postauricular pain, and as suspected, it's pain behind the ear. The NHS website confirmed that all of the above are Mastoiditis symptoms. It also mentioned that it's more likely to occur after a severe ear infection (I assume the Otitis was severe as it was treated by antibiotics, and the NHS website said middle ear infections don't always need antibiotic treatment).

The NHS website also mentioned that Mastoiditis may need a scan to diagnose, and that it should be diagnosed and treated quickly. This seemed to confirm that (B) was not the correct choice.

I then confirmed via the NHS website that the same listed symptoms are not also true for Otitis. Finally, assuming the child has suspected Mastoiditis, I double-confirmed that a CT scan would be the scan of choice for diagnosis.

At this point, I was completely sure that the correct choice was (A), as I had both proved that the AI was correct, and disproved that (B) is a good option. 

I set my probability at 100/0 and concluded my research early.

column16:
I thought this would be straightforward, but it wasn't.

Firstly, I looked up Miranda Rights and the Fifth Amendment to confirm that what I believed, and what the AI said, was true. This assertion, that this right protects individuals from incriminating themselves, seemed to confirm this.

But I wanted to check whether there was any chance of (A) being correct. I went back to the AI's response and looked up the hearsay rule, as it seems if the confession was admissible, it would be due to this.

My research seemed to indicate that no hearsay exceptions would apply to the out-of-court statement from accused A. 

But then I looked at the wording of the question. It was based on "“the fact that accused B did not object or respond to accused A's accusatory statement", rather than the statement itself. So what's important here is the fact they didn't respond, not the confession from accused A.

I looked up Miranda exceptions. This was a bit murky and the sources used a lot of legalese that was difficult to parse, but it became clear that the fact that accused B (apparently) hadn't explicitly waived their Miranda Rights might change things. They didn't assert their right to silence.

I then found a few instances where silence from the accused was accepted as incriminating, but it wasn't just simple silence by omitting to speak in these cases. It was silence when they had spoken previously, or silence with a change of demeanour, or silence when they'd be expected to ask about the wellbeing of others involved. This situation isn't the same – accused B just didn't speak.

I then tried to check whether it made a difference that the reading of the Miranda rights wasn't completed when accused A confessed. I didn't find any information on this, but I did find another website asserting that "In a recent U.S. Supreme Court ruling, the Court held in a 5-4 decision that in order to invoke the right to remain silent, one must do so unambiguously." Accused B didn't do this.

I also read that "statements are admissible as evidence against the suspect if they did not clearly invoke the right to remain silent or the right to an attorney." But would silence count as a statement?

I had already run out of time a few minutes prior, so with two lingering questions that were very difficult to answer (is silence a statement, and did it matter that the Miranda rights reading wasn't finished?) I went back to the question page. 

As previously mentioned, the question asks "whether the fact that accused B did not object or respond to accused A's accusatory statement" – this would seem to rule out silence counting as a statement being of any importance.

(I will note that before making my final response, I did miss the AI's assertion "The Supreme Court has ruled that a defendant's silence in response to an accusation cannot be used as evidence of guilt" – maybe this would have been helpful, but given the above paragraph, maybe not.)

In the end, I wasn't convinced either way. Going by the wording of the question, I still think that (B) is most likely the correct response. But perhaps the fact that accused B didn't assert their right to silence overturns this. Due to my lack of confidence either way, I assigned my probability as 45/55.

column16:
Given that the AI's response made perfect sense to me, I firstly decided to research the defendant's right to confront a witness. I didn't know exactly what this meant although I had an idea, so I thought this would help prove myself and the AI either right or wrong.

The definitions that I found confirmed that this constitutional right is about the defendant being able to cross-examine witnesses in court.

But then I thought, well, the defendant can't confront a photograph, can they? I did some further research on what might run afoul of the Confrontation Clause, and found that some out-of-court statements (including reports), especially from nontestifying witnesses, might qualify. 

I went back to re-read the question and the AI's response, to check whether the proprietor and specialist were testifying. The former wasn't mentioned, but the specialist did testify to its accuracy. I also clarified to myself that (A) focuses on the use of infrared imaging, not the photograph itself. The AI states that the infrared imaging was a tool to gather evidence, not a witness (and that evidence has been validated as authentic).

So, I then looked up Confrontation Clause + evidence, and then followed a webpage link to the definition of a witness. I then did some further research on this, and concluded that a witness is generally required to be human (i.e. not a tool for gathering evidence). Some very rare exceptions may have been presented in the past, but these 'witnesses' were still alive, e.g. animals.

I then looked up photo evidence in court, and found that (as the AI had stated), the photograph would be admissible as it meets the two requirements of relevance and authenticity.

I then checked use of infrared technology as evidence in case there was a legal loophole there, but the only time thermal imaging appears to be an issue (from my research) is when privacy is being violated, e.g. police using thermal imaging on private residences. And in any case, (A)'s argument focused on confronting witnesses, not infrared imaging being disallowed.

By this point, I was confident that the AI was correct. It's reasoning made sense, and I couldn't disprove any of its points (nor could I prove that (A)'s argument was valid). 

I concluded my research early, and set my probability at 0/100.

column16:
I firstly went to look up whether in the US, a release from a written contract obligation has to be in writing, but the search results were very generic. I then altered my search to remove the term "written contract", and found an LII webpage providing a definition of "release". Usually this website is good at providing understandable legal definitions, but in this case I don't think this page was relevant, "release" must have another meaning here.

I didn't have any luck reading up on the general definition of a contract on LII either, so I then looked up "verbal alteration to written contract". I found that verbal contract modifications can be challenging to prove in court, but while putting changes in writing is advised, it's not always required. 

I also noted that the website I used stated that contract modifications do require consideration.

I then found a website that specialised in US (albeit Florida-specific) construction law. It suggested that most legal problems in this area relate to verbal agreements that were made to alter written agreement. It also confirmed that if a contract doesn't state that verbal changes aren't allowed, a verbal change could be admissible: 

"A good rule of thumb is that if a verbal agreement or understanding contradicts an explicit term or subject in the contract it is inadmissible. If it does not, it may be admissible." 

In this case, no explicit term relating to this is mentioned in regards to this particular contract. So I think the change would be admissible.

I then went back to the question page and noted that (A)'s reasoning is generic. "Yes, because the release of a contractual obligation must be documented in writing." – (A) does not state "because IN THIS CONTRACT the release of...". Given that I had just found multiple reliable sources that stated that contract changes DON'T always have to be in writing, I believe (A) is an incorrect statement. So it can't possibly be the right answer. 

Now, I had to prove (B) was correct, or at least do enough research to persuade myself that I couldn't disprove it.

I had already learned that modifications to a contract require consideration. I then found this information on the LII website: 

"Good faith modification: A modified contract is a kind of new agreement, which changes parties’ obligations and then requires new consideration. But contract modification made in good faith under UCC is enforceable even without consideration."

So not only does a contract change require consideration, but it must be NEW consideration, unless it's made under UCC. 

My next step was to research UCC, and I found that UCC relates only to provision of goods; provision of services would fall under common law, not UCC.

Therefore, this contract modification would have required new consideration. But the consideration was not new; the previous consideration of $200k was maintained. The AI's statement that this could be considered consideration for the removal of the pavement installation duty is incorrect.

At this point, I was quite sure I had proved the AI incorrect, as new consideration would be a requirement, and (A) seems to be an incorrect statement. I concluded my research just a couple of minutes early, and set my probability at 20/80, because my reasoning for (A) is dependent on how it is worded rather than definitive knowledge of the contract terms, although I am still very certain that (B) is correct.

column16:
As mentioned, I initially interpreted this as X having been tricked by Z when he signed the contract. I thought X expected to get the orchard as he already thought Z had the title, since it mentioned that he wasn't aware of the legal situation.

I started by researching quitclaim deeds, since I didn't know what this was. I found confirmation of what the AI said around a quitclaim deed not guaranteeing that the grantor has any particular interest in the property. (But, if someone believes a quitclaim deed was used to illegally transfer a property, it can be challenged in court.)

With that out of the way, I then looked up contract estoppel. So rather than this being about promissory estoppel, which I had remembered from a previous question, estoppel in this case would prevent X from renouncing the validity of the contract.

I then looked up contract+renunciation+estoppel, and found that "generally, a party asserting estoppel must have “clean hands,” or be free from fault”. I'm not sure that Z is free from fault here, but this would explain why the AI seemed unsure of her victory.

I then researched contract acceptance via initial payment. On Law Stackexchange, someone asserted that yes, payment indicates contract acceptance, and gave examples that made sense to me. But, a contract acceptance generally hasn’t occurred if the offer is based on lies – did Z lie?

I then realised that this probably comes down to wording, so I revisited the question, the answers, and the AI's response.

(A) is worded that X "deliberately" negotiated the quitclaim deed "in anticipation" of securing the orchard – but as the AI asserts, he didn’t know of the legal situation, he wasn’t "deliberately" trying to get it knowing Z had no claim. And this would have been impossible to prove anyway, because the quitclaim deed doesn't guarantee Z even has a claim, so a quitclaim can't be used in this manner. This means that (A) can't possibly be the correct answer.

(B) seemed more likely at this point. By making a payment, X accepted the contract – as my online research found, this is how most contracts work. No need to even sign anything. It's a quitclaim, so if he did his due diligence and understood the terms, he'd have understood that Z didn't necessarily have a claim to transfer, so he wouldn't necessarily get anything. But he made that initial payment anyway.

Z already did her part by the time X made that payment. Z had already transferred 'her claim' on the property, whatever that may (or may not) be. So, contrary to my initial understanding, it's X who is 'in the wrong', as should have known what he was getting into when he willingly made that initial payment. 

My final probability of 15/85 reflects the fact that my reasoning is mostly based on how this was worded.

column16:
I think ultimately this comes down to how it was worded, and I think this tripped up the AI (and myself, to start with). 

I started by researching hearsay exceptions. It took a few attempts to make sense of the double-negative, legalese wording I was encountering, but I gathered that this probably wouldn't count as an exception to the hearsay rule due to it being a present sense impression (since it happened a while after the party), an excited utterance (it wasn't), and not an admission of a party opponent (I clarified that this means the person opposing the defendant in the trial, which the copassenger isn't). There were other exceptions listed but none looked likely.

I then went back to the AI's reasoning, and checked whether a hearsay rule exception could apply when "a statement is against the declarant's interest". It would, but I don't think it would apply here. The copassenger isn't the one on trial here, they are a potential witness, that's all. (Although I'd imagine one could get into trouble for knowingly allowing their driver to drink-drive.)

So, still thinking that (A) was the most plausible answer, since it probably wasn't a hearsay exception, I went about disproving (B). I read the LII definition of relevant evidence, and thought that the statement probably met that definition, as it "tends to make a fact more probable than it would be".

Then I went back to read the question. (By the way, was the copassenger a robot? I don't believe a human who had been drinking would make that statement in those actual words!)

As previously noted, the question stated that the copassenger was ready and willing to give their testimony during the court trial. So wouldn't that be testimony then, rather than hearsay? I did some research around this, and found that if the copassenger delivered the information that they had come from a party where everyone had been drinking as testimony in court, this could not be hearsay. I think the only way it could be hearsay would be if the copassenger limited their testimony to "yes, I made that statement to the officer at the scene". But why would they come into court just to say that and not give their version of events?

I then noted from the question that the court was eager to have the OFFICER recount the statement, not the copassenger. And the question asks about the copassenger's TESTIMONY. So from this, I gather they did deliver testimony, so it isn't the statement that is in question.

Finally, I thought about their statement. How could it be irrelevant? Well, although they said everyone at the party had been drinking, they didn't say the DRIVER was at the party. The driver could have been a taxi driver, or just a friend who collected them from the party but didn't actually attend. When they made that statement, it was out of earshot of the driver (so they had no opportunity to clarify that they weren't there), and it could have been given for another reason, i.e. to explain why the driver had come to pick them up (because copassenger had been drinking). 

I concluded that, not knowing whether the driver had been at the party, and considering the wording of (B) "Not admissible, due to the fact it could POTENTIALLY steer...", (B) is most likely the correct response. 

I kept my probability low, at 45/55, because it is not known whether the driver was at the party, or whether the copassenger is testifying only to confirm that they made that statement at the scene and nothing more. I think (A) is still possible, but (B) is more likely. 

(I also think the officer should have just breathalysed the driver at the scene.)

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 50%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 50%
column7: I had no idea.
column10: After reading the AI's answer: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 25%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 75%
column11: The AI's explanation made sense; if an invasive procedure could be avoided, the CT scan seemed like the best way to go, especially if it's more accurate.
column14: After my research: A (Diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL)): 100%; B (Abdominal CT scan): 0%
column16:
I firstly looked up diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL), as I hadn't a clue what this entailed. I found that while yes, it is invasive, it was noted that it's a good alternative to a CT scan when the patient is unstable or uncooperative, as you'd need to sedate them for a CT scan. Also, DPL is quicker than a CT scan. Since the patient is described as having cognitive impairment, I conclude that he's conscious and likely unstable (as in, might not be able to keep still).

I then looked up what a GCS score of 10 means. This would indicate a moderate brain injury. Another indication that he might be considered unstable.

I then noted his pelvic fractures and looked up a visual of the ischal rami. I concluded that if both sides of his pelvis are broken, he's not going to be comfortable lying in a CT scanner for a prolonged period of time.

I then looked up how long an abdominal CT scan takes. It "should take less than 30 minutes" (so it's not short), you must hold still the whole time, and you may need to hold your breath. 

I don't think this patient is in a state to be able to do any of these things.

I also noted that he's obese, and while his weight isn't stated, some CT scanners can't take more than 135kg.

I then reread the AI's response for any more clues, although I was now leaning heavily towards (A).

It noted that DPL isn't good on an unstable patient, so I looked that up. I found that DPL is used on patients for whom clinical exam of abdomen is unreliable due to traumatic brain injury or multiple associated injuries, both of which the patient has. I did note that morbid obesity can be a relative contraindication to DPL, but the question doesn’t state that he’s morbidly obese, and if he were, would he be able to work a physical job like bricklaying?

I then saw a sentence that sealed my decision. CT scanning requires a "hemodynamically normal patient". I double-checked, and due to his blood loss, heart rate and BP, this patient is definitely not hemodynamically normal.

I then confirmed via the NIH website that "In a hemodynamically abnormal patient, if FAST is unavailable or results are equivocal, DPL is indicated."

The correct answer is definitely (A). I set my probability at 100/0 to reflect this.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 50%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 50%
column7: I had no idea.
column10: After reading the AI's answer: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 40%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 60%
column11: The AI's explanation seemed convincing, especially as it had cited a rule that I could look up. I did note though that the AI's response didn't touch on "inappropriate character evidence", so I wondered whether this line of questioning could still be objected to (for being inappropriate) during a cross-examination.
column14: After my research: A (Omitted, as it constitutes inappropriate character evidence.): 55%; B (Admitted, but only if itâ€™s obtained from the expert witness during cross examination.): 45%
column16:
(Note: sorry, this video is longer than the others. I ran over time a bit (although I believe that's permitted). I also got called away part-way through; I paused the video then but forgot to pause the timer.)

I firstly researched Rule 608(b), which the AI had referenced. The wording seemed to concur with what the AI had said: specific instances of conduct may be inquired into on cross-examination if they are probative of the character for un/truthfulness of the witness.

I checked the meaning of "probative", and my understanding was correct – it means having the quality of proving or demonstrating something.

This Rule 608 does have exceptions and a lot of notes, however. I don't think this is as straightforward as the AI is making it out to be, and the legalese is difficult to parse.

I decided it was quicker to take the alternative route and look up character evidence.

I first got caught up reading about character evidence in criminal and federal cases, then realised this probably doesn't apply. I think, from my research, that this would be a common law case. I then realised that some of the information on character evidence was about plaintiffs or defendants' characters, not witnesses. Everything seemed to circle back to Rule 608.

I did find that "Evidence of a witness’s character may be admitted under rules 607, 608 & 609", but rules 607 & 609 related specifically to impeachment and criminal witnesses. These didn't seem relevant; I was back to Rule 608. So far the AI seems to be correct.

I tried again to research around 'witness character evidence'. It was back to Rule 608 again, but I noticed something. Rule 608 states:

"the court may, on cross-examination, allow [specific instances of conduct] to be inquired into if they are probative of the character for truthfulness or untruthfulness of:

(1) the witness; or

(2) another witness whose character the witness being cross-examined has testified about."

My understanding here is that the second point indicates that the character evidence could be obtained by cross-examining the witness themself, OR someone else.

As I type this I'm now doubting myself, but I took this to mean that (B) could not be true, as it states that the evidence could ONLY be obtained by cross-examining the expert witness. 

(However I'm now realising that this might still apply, as no other witnesses are mentioned, and the respondent who knows about this evidence is a defendant, not a witness.)

I then concluded that (A) might be possible if the judge decided that the character evidence was irrelevant or misleading. The expert witness was giving evidence on finances; it's not clear what type of false testimony they gave previously (whether financial or otherwise) or even whether it was their own marital dissolution proceedings or that of the respondent.

I also noted that in this case, they are an expert witness, but they wouldn't have been an expert witness if it was their own marital dissolution proceedings. 

I wasn't sure if either of those last two points would be relevant, as I was unable to find information about irrelevant witness character evidence during my research.

Due to my understanding that (B) could not be true as it excluded the possibility of other witnesses being cross-examined, I tentatively chose (A) as the correct answer. 

I set my probability at 55/45 due to my uncertainty, and the fact that my conclusion was based on how this was worded more than having proven (A) correct.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (djedi li pa fa lo nu lo tamca coâ€™a xunre): 50%; B (djedi li pa fa lo nu lo tamca cu xunre carna): 50%

It suggested the verb is at the end of the sentence, then picked the answer where the verb is NOT at the end of the sentence (unless it doesn’t have to be the very last word). I didn't consider myself to have a better idea of the answer after reading the AI's response.
column14: After my research: A (djedi li pa fa lo nu lo tamca coâ€™a xunre): 100%; B (djedi li pa fa lo nu lo tamca cu xunre carna): 0%
column16:
First, I looked up the definition of 'xunre'. It means 'red', thus confirming that in (A), the verb would not be at the end of the sentence as the AI asserts it should be. But I wondered whether it meant a vague "around the end" or whether it literally had to be the final word in the sentence.

I then looked up Lojban sentence structure. I learned that the 'selbri' in a sentence would probably compare to English verbs (but it wouldn't always be a 1:1 comparison with English). I then learned that the selbri does not have to be the last word in a sentence, although it would sit towards the end. I'm going to ignore this part of the AI's explanation.

I then looked up "carna". I should have done this first, because the definition of "to turn about a vector" clearly excludes (B) from being the possible response. This is a physical turning, not a 'becoming' turning, as the apple does when it turns red.

I confirmed that "co'a" does indeed mean "to become". 

I realised that perhaps the way in which Lojban sentences are put together means that "co'a xunre" might indeed serve as a type of verb "to redden" (which would mean the verb comes last), but this wasn't relevant so I didn't look into this further.

After reconfirming the definitions of both words in another Lojban-English dictionary with example sentences, I was 100% sure that (A) was the correct answer. I concluded my research early, and set my probability at 100/0.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka klaku ku poâ€™o kakne): 50%; B (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka krixa ku poâ€™o kakne): 50%
column7: I had no idea.
column10: After reading the AI's answer: A (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka klaku ku poâ€™o kakne): 80%; B (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka krixa ku poâ€™o kakne): 20%

column14: After my research: A (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka klaku ku poâ€™o kakne): 100%; B (ca lo mronunsla mi lo ka krixa ku poâ€™o kakne): 0%
column16:
I firstly went to confirm the definitions of "klaku" and "krixa" in a Lojban-English dictionary.

"klaku" means weeps/cries tears.
"krixa" means cries out/yells/howls sound.

This seems to prove the AI correct. However, I do consider that both verbs are possible actions at a funeral, but klaku is more likely. If I could do nothing but weep, I wouldn’t be howling or crying out. Although in this case "krixa" could mean I could do nothing but howl.

I then confirmed the definitions in another Lojban-English dictionary, checking example sentences. It confirmed that "klaku" is to weep, and suggested that "krixa" is more of a "cry out/shout/yell" action. 

Going by context, we'd expect weeping at a funeral much more than shouting or yelling, but again, both are possible.

I reread the question. It's asking about the correct translation from the English, not which verb is more likely to be correct in Lojban. In English, "cry" means to "weep", not to "shout/yell/howl" etc. "Cry out" could mean those things, but in the context of the sentence, we can assume that "cry" means "weep".

So, (A) is the correct definition, since "klaku" means to "weep". (B) is an incorrect translation.

I concluded my research early, and set my probability at 100/0.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Wait and watch): 50%; B (Organising an abdominal CT scan): 50%
column7: I had no idea.

column16:
I started by researching Varicoceles, which the AI stated was the most likely cause. I found that this usually occurs on the left-hand side of the scrotum, but occurrence on the right-hand side is possible (as with this patient). I also noted that Varicoceles most often occurs during puberty, but this patient is 45, and only noticed the mass a week previously.

Multiple websites throughout my research confirmed that the "bag of worms" descriptions seems to fit Varicoceles.

I then decided to make my search more specific: ""bag of worms" mass on scrotum right”.

The Johns Hopkins medical website provided some important information:

"if a varicocele forms on the right side and not the left, it is important to make sure there is no mass or other abnormality in the abdomen that might be causing it.”

This contradicts the AI's advice, and also seems to suggest an abdominal CT scan is appropriate.

The same website also stated:

"When a varicocele doesn’t reduce [when a patient is lying down], it also raises concern that there is an abdominal blockage such as a mass or tumor that could be causing the mass."

It is mentioned in the description that the mass remains the same when the patient lies down. Again, there's a suggestion of an abdominal blockage, which would presumably require an abdominal CT scan to diagnose.

I then did some further research with the aim of confirming this information. I was now quite sure that the AI was wrong. I didn't find much information to confirm what the Johns Hopkins website had said, but I'm aware that a lot of public-facing medical websites take care to limit information that might cause unnecessary distress to patients researching their symptoms, and the information I had found previously went a little beyond the reassuring, 'need to know' facts.

I did eventually find a statement on WebMD that confirmed that the mass should disappear when the patient lies down. Multiple other websites confirmed that it tends to occur on the left hand side, and in younger patients (but this is not absolute).

I then decided to research CT scan radiation risk, since this was one of the AI's reasons for not getting a scan. A couple of academic and medical websites suggested that for a one-off CT scan, the overall risk from radiation is low.

At this stage, given what I had read on the Johns Hopkins website, and knowing that the CT scan didn't pose a significant risk, I decided that the AI was definitely incorrect.

I set my probability at 15/85 as although I was certain, this was based mostly on a single (albeit trustworthy) website, rather than having been backed up by many sources.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 50%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 50%
column7: I had no idea.

column11: The AI's response appeared confident; I just needed to prove it right.
column14: After my research: A (Intravenous erythromycin): 20%; B (Nasogastric tube decompression): 80%
column16:
I firstly researched small bowel obstruction (SBO) symptoms. I found that while the listed symptoms seemed to match what the AI was saying, I suspected they were quite generic and could indicate other conditions as well.

I then decided to research the listed symptoms individually, and understood that:
- The patient does not have fever
- His BP is high
- His HR is high-ish
- I think his white blood cell count is high, but it was tricky to tell as the web page didn't render the character encoding correctly.

I then researched "dilated bowel loops". The symptoms of this again seemed to match, but were all generic. I decided to research the two treatment options instead.

I quickly discovered that (A) erythromycin is an antibiotic, used for treating infections. The patient does not have fever, which I know usually indicates infection, so it doesn't seem like this is the problem here.

While erythromycin can be used to stimulate the bowels, I doubt that an antibiotic would be used for this instead of a purpose-made laxative. And if the patient has a bowel obstruction, stimulating the bowels might not help and could be dangerous. 

I did also find that erythromycin is used to treat gastoparesis, but the patient's problem is with the bowels, not the stomach, so this isn't relevant.

I then researched (B) Nasogastric tube decompression. I found this this is definitely a treatment for bowel blockages, as the AI asserted.

So then I decided to determine whether the patient most likely has a bowel blockage.

"Dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels" does, according to my research, suggest bowel obstruction. Bilious vomiting, which the patient is also experiencing, is also a sign of SBO. Although it has other causes, none seemed to fit the scenario, and I saw no indication that bilious vomiting would indicate an infection.

I was then feeling quite sure that (B) was correct, but decided to go back and check whether anything came up for SBO+Erythromycin. While it seems that this drug can be used to prevent SBO, e.g. after surgery, it isn't used as a treatment, except possibly in cases of pseudo obstruction (which this isn't).

Finally, I confirmed that gastrointestinal decompression is suggested for patients "with significant distension, nausea, and/or vomiting" – which our patient has.

I set my probabilities at 20/80 since I didn't 'prove' that the patient had SBO, although it seems quite certain (and lack of fever may rule out infection). Assuming SBO, I had confirmed that (B) would definitely be the best next step in terms of treatment.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (The plumbing supply corporation is obligated to deliver 25 sets on March 1, and the property manager is required to pay the agreed price for the 25 sets within a timeframe that can be considered reasonable following their delivery.): 55%; B (The plumbing supply corporation is under no obligation to deliver the 25 sets on March 1 at the plumbing supply corporationâ€™s headquarters unless the property manager presents the agreed price for the 25 sets on that specified date.): 45%
column7: This was just a hunch. The company was definitely obligated to deliver given that this date was in the contract, and the idea of a "reasonable timeframe" sounded... reasonable.

column16:
Firstly, I looked up the UCC, and tried to find the section that discusses payment terms, as this is the part that the AI contradicted itself on. It was difficult to find the relevant section, as the websites I had accessed all used 'legalese' and were full of jargon that I couldn't understand easily.

I eventually found a website that explained the UCC terms in plain English. It confirmed that:

"the seller will deliver the goods to their own place of business as long as the goods aren't known by both parties to be kept somewhere else."

And that the seller must then hold onto the goods until the buyer can pick them up. This seems to confirm the 'delivery' part of the answer.

I then checked the same website for the buyer's obligations RE payment:

"The general rule is that the buyer must accept and pay for the goods when the seller has delivered—or, to use more technical language, "tendered delivery of"—the goods."

And, importantly:

"More particularly, the UCC indicates that by default and unless otherwise agreed to:
the seller's delivery of the goods and the buyer's payment for the goods are expected to happen at the same time."

Since the payment must take place at the same time as delivery, this would suggest that (B) is correct.

However, I then noticed that the buyer can hold off payment until they've "accepted" the goods, i.e. had time to inspect them first to check they aren't defective. The buyer would by default need to inspect the goods at the seller's location, but they can do so at "any reasonable place and time".

These are bathroom sets, so they might take a while to inspect. I decided to search UCC wording specifically around the term "reasonable timeframe", but didn't find relevant results.

The nice, understandable website didn't say anything about payment within a reasonable period of time if it wasn't agreed. I decided to go back to the wording of the question and answers.

Although we know that the seller IS obligated to deliver 25 sets on March 1, this doesn't necessarily mean (A) is correct. Since the website I had visited earlier stated that "the seller's delivery of the goods and the buyer's payment for the goods are expected to happen at the same time”, this suggests that (B) is more correct. If the buyer doesn't present payment at the same time, it's breaching the UCC rules, so I assume then the seller wouldn't be obligated to deliver under UCC.

I tried again to confirm some of the UCC details, and found that:

"2-310. Open Time for Payment or Running of Credit; Authority to Ship Under Reservation.
o	Unless otherwise agreed
o	(a) payment is due at the time and place at which the buyer is to receive the goods even though the place of shipment is the place of delivery"

Although this had the same caveat that the buyer may inspect the goods first, it didn't use wording around paying within a reasonable timeframe.

I then researched what would be a commercially reasonable time under UCC. I found that:

"2-309: The time for shipment or delivery or any other action under a contract if not provided in this Article or agreed upon shall be a reasonable time."

Payment would constitute "any other action", but the time for payment was specified in the UCC Article 2 (Sales) as being by default at the time of delivery, so I assume this 2-309 clause would not apply.

I decided that this easily confusable information may have caused the AI to hallucinate its statement regarding payment that  "a reasonable time is implied if not specified."

I set my final answer as (B), and I set my probability at 40/60 because this was tricky to research, and although I believe I've found the right answer, there's still some ambiguity around the buyer being allowed to pay after inspection of goods, and how long that might take.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 50%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 50%
column7: I had no idea.
column10: After reading the AI's answer: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 70%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 30%
column11: I quickly tried to parse and follow the AI's explanation, and it seemed to fit, although I'd need to work it out properly and check the definitions.
column14: After my research: A (smaji coâ€™u ku coâ€™a lo nu lo cipni cu cmoni): 90%; B (smaji coâ€™u lo nu lo cipni coâ€™a cmoni): 10%
column16:
I copied the two Lojban sentences into my separate notes document on my other screen, and started to parse them out, using the AI's explanations.

If the AI's definitions were correct, then Lojban translation (B) would indeed be the incorrect answer:

(B) smaji co'u | lo nu | lo cipni | co'a cmoni
The quietness ends | (turns bridi into a noun) | the birds | start sing
“the quietness ends [the noun of the birds starting to sing]” 

(I showed my document on-screen in the video a few times as I worked through the sentences.)

I then looked up the missing words/particles in sentence (A) that the AI had not defined in its explanation ('ku' and 'cu'). I just used a Lojban dictionary and Wiktionary for this; I did try to read up on a grammar usage website and on Reddit, but as Lojban vocabulary was used, I didn't understand these explanations.

I found that 'ku' works as a terminator. I assume then that in its use below, it terminates the verb co'u (to end) so that it applies to the quietness, not what comes next (after 'ku').

I then found that 'cu' is a separator. I wasn't too sure how this worked, but I assumed it helped turn "the noun of the birds singing" into "birdsong".

My translation for (A) now looked correct:

(A)	smaji co'u | ku | co'a | lo nu | lo cipni | cu | cmoni
the quietness ends | [terminator/end desc] | start | (turns bridi into a noun) | the birds | (separator) | sing
“the quietness ends, the birdsong starts”

I then checked the definitions of the other Lojban words, not wanting to take the AI at its word. The AI's definitions proved correct.

I set my final probability at 90/10 because although I parsed out and translated the sentences myself, I still didn't fully understand all of the words/particles. I also leaned heavily on the AI's explanation while doing my research.

column6: Before reading the AI's answer: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 60%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 40%
column7: I leaned towards (A) as the explanation made most sense to me. The dealer did mislead, and I didn't really see how the contract could be oppressively unfair.
column10: After reading the AI's answer: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 60%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 40%
column11: The AI's explanation more or less matched what I had been thinking (but in more detail). However, this didn't increase my certainty since I'd still need to prove it right (or not).
column14: After my research: A (Yes, the buyer is likely to win because the dealerâ€™s statement was deliberately misleading, and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer.): 70%; B (Yes, the buyer stands a good chance of winning because the contract was oppressively unfair.): 30%
column16:
I firstly searched on US contract law + misrepresentation, since the AI used this term. I found that an omission which renders statements misleading may constitute a misrepresentation – this seems to fit what happened.

I wasn't as certain that the description of "fraudulent misrepresentation" fit the scenario (the AI had mentioned this as well), but in this case I think either of the 'misrepresentations' mentioned could apply and the buyer would win.

I then decided to research option (B). An "oppressively unfair" contract in the US would be one that is declared "unconscionable". Going by the descriptions I read, I don't believe this contract was unconscionable. Although "abuses" did take place by the dealer during the contract's formation, I don't think the buyer had an absence of meaningful choice, as they did have the option to have a mechanic inspect the vehicle. Also, according to the LII website:

"A contract is most likely to be found unconscionable if both unfair bargaining and unfair substantive terms are shown."

Nothing is mentioned in the description of the contract terms being unfair.

I then looked up what would be needed to rescind a contract in the US.

I did end up on Wikipedia, which I'm aware isn't always the most reliable source, but the language there was easier to understand. I found (again) that a contract can be rescinded due to misrepresentation, described as:

"To amount to a misrepresentation, the statement must be untrue or seriously misleading. A statement which is "technically true" but which gives a misleading impression is deemed an "untrue statement".

The dealer's statement, according to this description, would definitely be "untrue". And since misrepresentation is a valid reason to rescind a contract (which the buyer is trying to do), (A) seems even more likely to be the correct answer at this point.

I then looked up "misrepresentation by omission", as the dealer had omitted the detail about the car being in an accident, and this is what the wording in (A) focuses on.

According to LII: "A misrepresentation is a false or misleading statement or a material omission" – so yes, misrepresentation definitely applies in this case, I've just double (or triple) confirmed it.

I did wonder about whether the part of (A) that reads "and evidence of the accident was hidden by the dealer" was important, as yes the dealer did hide the evidence, but one would expect them to repair and repaint the car before selling it – I'm sure this isn't a problem. I assume in this case, the "hiding of evidence" again would be through the combination of both physical repair and verbal omission. 

I reread what makes a contract unconscionable, just in case I had missed anything, but I still agree that the terms weren't unfair, and as the AI pointed out, the buyer had the option to have a mechanic inspect the vehicle. The Wikipedia definition of unconscionability uses words like "extreme" and "no reasonable or informed person would otherwise agree to it", which I didn't feel applied in this case.

I set my probability at 70/30, because I felt I hadn't "proven" the AI correct beyond all doubt, although I do believe (A) is the correct answer.

column16:
Firstly I confirmed the definitions: "spali" = "polish", and "jadni" = "decoration/adornment".

"Nail polish" is a compound word. Technically, nail polish doesn't "polish" the nail like, say, furniture polish does; this would be closer to nail buffing. Nail polish does decorate the nail, though.

I tried looking up "varnish" as "nail varnish" is sometimes used as a synonym for "nail polish", but "varnish" is another word entirely in Lojban.

I then looked up "paint", since nail polish does "paint" the nail. But again, "paint" is a separate word in Lojban, and not one of our two choices.

I then looked up "spali" and "jadni" in another Lojban dictionary in the hope that it would have some example sentences involving nail polish, but had no luck there.

I then checked what types of words "jadni" and "spali" are in Lojban. Both are gismu, so this didn't help. I had thought that perhaps if jadni had exclusively been a verb, for example, this would have provided a clue. But I don't think I can eliminate or do further helpful research based on grammar.

I then simply tried searching on 'Lojban + "nail polish"' in case I had any luck. I did find what I believe to be a translation! Unfortunately, that translation used another term for polish ("grasu," also a gismu), which translates to English as "oil". 

So if this translation is to be believed (and I do trust it, since it is in an official Lojban publication, and Lojban is designed not to be ambiguous), "nail polish" translates to "nail oil" in Lojban.

This did help. The question only asks which is the "better" translation, not which is "correct".

"Polish", as a tangible thing, is much closer to "oil" than an "adornment" is. 

Yes, nail polish is technically an adornment of the nails, but "jgalu grasu" from the Lojban publication does not directly translate to "nail polish", while "jgalu spali" does.

Finally, the focus of the sentence is on the smell. Polish (in general) is known to be a smelly substance. A decoration could be anything; if I think "decoration" I don't immediately think "smelly". I think in this sentence, "jgalu spali" is a better translation of "nail polish", because it emphasises the smell. And other nail adornments do exist (sequins, stickers etc) that do not smell.

Therefore, I think the correct answer is (A). I set my probability at 70/30 because I didn't definitively prove this either way. (And what consists of a "better" translation could be subjective, given neither are apparently the "correct" translation!)

column16:
The first thing I did was look up "US contract implied-in-fact". 

From the LII website, I found that:

"A contract implied in fact consists of obligations arising from a mutual agreement expressed not through words but implied through actions."

This was of interest, as the note seems to me more like "words" than "actions". The lawyer simply came across the paper; it doesn't expressly mention that it was posted, faxed or emailed to him, which I'd see as more of an "action". I wondered if I was barking up the wrong tree, however.

I then found another LII entry for "contract implied in fact" – the former page was "implied contract". I wondered if these were different legal concepts, but a later search showed that they probably pertain to the same thing (but the "implied contract" page refers to both "implied in fact" and "implied in law" contracts).

I did find some interesting information on this LII "contract implied in fact" page however:

"To establish the existence of an implied in fact contract, it is necessary to show:
o	An unambiguous offer, 
o	Unambiguous acceptance, 
o	Mutual intent to be bound, and
o	Consideration"

I don't believe any of these conditions were met. Maybe by conducting the work, the lawyer met "unambiguous acceptance". And maybe, if the legal firm had some sort of price list, the "consideration" could have been assumed by default. But the note didn't mention consideration, and as the client is asserting, it didn't present an unambiguous offer or mutual intent to be bound.

I decided at this point that (A) seemed the less likely option. But how to research (B)?

I tried researching things like "US contract action disadvantage", but couldn't find anything relevant. I couldn't think of how to phrase this in a way to get relevant results.

I went back down the route of trying to disprove (A) instead.

I tried "US implied-in-fact contract unenforceable", and also tried searches using the term "no value", as the LII had mentioned earlier that:

"However, under some circumstances, even if a defendant has received nothing of value, the implied-in-fact contract can still be enforced."

But again, I didn't find anything of use. I did find an Investopedia definition of contract implied-in-fact (I like this website because it uses plain English), which backed up the LII description by stating that this type of contract requires an offer and acceptance of the offer, mutual agreement, and consideration. Again, I don't think these terms were met.

Perhaps if a precedence had been mentioned (if the lawyer had done this type of work for the client before on a regular basis) it would have steered me back to (A), but there's no indication of this. Writing up a will is a different type of work to checking a contract, and I don't think the two are comparable.

Finally, I found this, also on Investopedia:

"Implied-in-fact assumes that parties understand the terms of the agreement and what actions must be taken."

Again, there was no indication that both parties understood any terms. 

I was running out of time and getting nowhere – this one was very tricky, and even the AI was unsure! – so I kept my probability at 45/55. I didn't prove either answer, but I think I came closer to disproving (A).

column16:
Firstly, I went to the Lojban dictionary to check the English meaning of "mi'o". The definition was:

"me/we the speaker(s)/author(s) & you the listener(s)."

I then checked "mi'a":

"me/we the speaker(s)/author(s) & others unspecified, but not you, the listener."

This confirmed the AI's translation.

I then clicked through to a page that delves into Lojban grammar in more detail, and confirmed that mi'o includes only the speaker and the listener but no-one else, and mi'a includes the speaker and others but excludes the listener.

I then thought about when mi'a might be applied. Could it be applied here? After all, the English phrase doesn't say "let's watch the sunset *together*".

Assuming this phrase was spoken, I don't think there's any ambiguity – the listener is clearly included as they are the one being spoken to, and "let's" is used.

But what if it were written? That same phrase in a book would refer to characters, but not the reader. Would the reader count as the listener here? Maybe not if it were dialogue in a book, but I thought it was worth checking.

I decided to verify the definitions of the other Lojban words in the sentence, mostly to check whether any were described by the dictionary as "literary" words (hinting at a book context), but also to confirm the AI was correct.

I found that the definitions matched the AI's assertions, and the concept of any being "literary" was not mentioned.

I then searched on literary vs spoken Lojban. This took me to the Wikipedia page, which asserted that Lojban is a *spoken* and unambiguous language, and that there isn't a lot of Lojban literature in existence. I assume then, that there is one standard version of Lojban, and therefore, even if this phrase did come from a book, there is no way that "mi'a" (B) could apply.

I set my probability at 80/20 because while I was quite certain, there's ultimately no way of knowing the context in which the phrase was uttered. In the context of it being standalone though, I do think it's clear that the correct answer is (A).

column16:
This was trickier than I had expected it to be.

I firstly looked up 'circumferential neck burn' as I thought this might mention something about the airway – I also wasn't sure what it meant (whether the burn was internal or external etc). It means the patient received burns all the way around the outside of the neck, but there was no indication that it necessitated an endotracheal tube.

I then looked up fluid resus for burns, and quickly found the following on the NIH website:

“It is a widely accepted fact that severe fluid loss is the greatest problem faced following major burn injuries [over 20%].”

I then read up on burn shock, as this seemed to be the AI's main concern. This tends to peak around 6-8 hours after the injury, but is better prevented than treated. Physiopedia confirmed that in patients with burn injuries over 20%, proper fluid resus is crucial within the first 24hrs after the injury.

However, I then read that haemodynamically stable patients may not benefit from fluid resus as this could lead to oedema. I checked whether the patient would be considered stable, according to his vital stats. His BP is normal, but his HR is on the higher end of normal. His respiratory rate is high. But I'm not sure whether this is important as an abnormal vital sign (necessitating fluid resus), or a sign of breathing difficulty (necessitating intubation).

I then looked up "occasional premature ventricular contractions". This isn't normally a cause for concern, but can indicate an electrolyte imbalance (which I suspect fluid resus would address) or stress and anxiety. If the patient is conscious, I bet he's stressed.

I'm still unsure which should come first. I'm not sure if he needs the tube, and I know he most likely needs the fluid resus. Even if his vitals aren't too abnormal, he has a very high % of burns.

I looked up how long it takes to insert an endotracheal tube. This should only take 30 seconds, so it's not going to delay the fluid resus by long. But does he need it? Won't it create discomfort and stress him out further if he doesn't need it?

I then found an NHS website that discussed how paramedic and hospital staff should assess patients presenting with burn injuries. It suggests that ambulance staff should begin to administer fluids if the ride to the hospital is likely to take over an hour – so they do need to get on it, fast. 

Meanwhile, although assessing breathing was a priority on the checklist, our patient didn't seem to meet any of the criteria listed that would necessitate "early intubation". 

After assessment of the wound is complete (this has already been done this in the question, as it's been assessed that the patient is at 43% burns), the next step from the NHS website is IV fluid resus for any patient with burns over 20%. Checking smoke inhalation injuries is the *next* step after that – and we can't do that if there's a tube down his throat, surely?

At this point, the timer was up, and I didn't feel that any further research would necessarily throw up new information. I kept my probability at 40/60 in favour of (B), because all the websites emphasised the importance of fluid resus soon after the burn injury, and because of how the patient did not appear to be having breathing difficulties. However, I wasn't able to conclusively prove that this is the correct next step, and given how quick it would be to intubate (and the patient's high breathing rate), I still have my doubts.

column16:
I firstly looked up the LII definition of hearsay to remind myself. Yes, going by the description, the driver's statement that was recounted by the officer would fall under the definition of hearsay.

The AI made the argument that it could be excluded from the hearsay rule as an excited utterance, but going by the definition, I don't think this applies. It wasn't said in the heat of the moment – the driver followed the car to the fast-food restaurant, then went to seek out the officer.

The other listed exceptions don't apply either – it's not a "statement against interest" on the driver's part, and it's not a matter of record.

I followed some other links on the LII website, to get more detail.

Another exception to the hearsay rule is the "present sense impression". I wonder about this for a moment, but then, on re-reading the question, I see that the driver made the statement to the officer 10 minutes after the accident. So it's not a present sense impression either.

At this point, I'm sure this is hearsay, and that none of the exceptions apply, making (A) the correct answer. But I decide to research (B) to disprove it.

I find that, according to LII:

“Unfair prejudice” within its context means an undue tendency to suggest decision on an improper basis, commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one." 

I don’t think someone approaching the officer to report a crime is an “improper basis", and I don't think the officer presenting information that directly relates to the charge is improper, either.

I then find a document on the Indiana University website that reads:

“In order for a danger to “substantially” outweigh probative value, the probative value must be pretty small, i.e., be of little or no relevance to begin with. You can’t exclude evidence that a child was molested as unfairly prejudicial if the defendant is on trial for that act."

This is the same. This is evidence that the defendant hit a person with their car, and the defendant is on trial for hitting that person with their car. So this can't be excluded as prejudicial. It's also not overly emotional evidence, as per the other sections of the Prejudice Rule.

I re-read the question and answer one more time. Yes, this is definitely hearsay. It even mentions that the driver was "anonymous" and "unidentified". And yes, the driver's statement was relevant, and not unfair, given that the officer then found the driver, as described, in the same car in the same fast food car park afterwards.

I'm 100% confident that the correct answer is (A).

column16:
I decided that the best approach would be to parse out each sentence. I did this in a separate doc on my other screen, and I showed it in the video a few times as I worked on it.

I first decided to tackle the definition of "zmanei". The Lojban dictionary entry for this word appeared to be very complicated! I'm not sure if it's a compound term, or if other terms are compounded from this one, but it does seem to be related to "liking" something, as well as "preferring" something.

"Nelmau" proved even tricker to define. A Lojban dictionary entry doesn't seem to exist for this word. After some searching, I eventually found a Lojban glossary that defined "-mau" as "-more-than". I assume here, then, that "-mau" is a suffix attached to "nel-" to indicate "something-more-than". 

To my understanding, "-mau" works like this for the following compound words, so I'm assuming it applies this way here:

“citno” means “young”, and “citmau” = “is younger than”
"gleki” is happy, and “gekmau” = “is happier than”

Going back to the "zmanei" definition, this word appears related to another word, "nelci", meaning "is fond of". 

"nel(ci)" + "mau" = "is fond of-more than" ("nelmau")?

I had, in the meantime, looked up the other word definitions, and had completed a rough parsed English translation of both sentences:

(A) la .mark. | cu | zmanei | lo’e | tcati | la .djein.

= Mark | (separator) | prefers | (descriptor) | tea | Jane

(B) la .mark. | cu | nelmau | la .djein. | lo'e | tcati

= Mark | (separator) | likes-more-than? | Jane | (descriptor) | tea 

Lojban sentences are formed in the order subject-verb-object.

Mark is the subject.
Likes (or, here, "likes-more-than-Jane") is the verb.
Tea is the object.

Therefore, the structure of (B) would make most sense as a translation. 

I set my probability at 40/60 because I definitely did not prove this beyond any doubt, and "zmanei" does appear to be related not just to "liking" but to "preferring" as well. However, "preferring" is different to "more than" – Mark doesn't "prefer" tea over Jane here (and Jane isn't the object of the sentence in English). I'm fairly confident that (B) is the correct translation.

column16:
When I looked up "US court child testimony", the first publication I encountered (which seemed reliable but was actually more geared towards children's health) stated that:

"The qualifications for a child to provide testimony include the following:
-	sufficient intelligence, understanding, and ability to observe, recall, and communicate events;
-	an ability to comprehend the seriousness of an oath; and
-	an appreciation of the necessity to tell the truth."

Then, the LII website stated (*emphasis* my own):

o	"*A child is presumed to be competent.*
o	A competency examination regarding a child witness may be conducted by the court *only upon written motion and offer of proof of incompetency by a party*.
o	A competency examination regarding a child may be conducted *only if the court determines, on the record, that compelling reasons exist*. *A child’s age alone is not a compelling reason*.
o	Psychological and psychiatric examinations to assess the competency of a child witness *shall not be ordered without a showing of compelling need*."

The first statement from the publication supports both answers (since proving the child is capable isn't mentioned, but "qualifications" might imply this), but the LII information clearly supports (A), since the question does not mention any challenge to the child's presumed competence. It seems as if "compelling evidence" isn't needed.

I then looked again at the AI's response. Its reasoning for (A) being incorrect is that it doesn't mention the need to assess a child's ability to provide a reliable testimony. But, as we've established, proof isn't needed, and the wording "delivering a truthful account" covers the "truthful testimony" part (just without using the same words).

I then searched on. A US government website stated that children are automatically allowed to testify under 601 of the Federal Rules of Evidence, which states that every person is competent to be a witness. However, some states hold that hold that children below certain ages, usually 10, 12, or 14, are presumptively incompetent unless determined otherwise. I decided to disregard that latter piece of information, as no state is mentioned in the question, so I assume that I should go by the Federal law.

The same government website then went on:

"To testify, a child must have certain characteristics, including the capacity to observe, sufficient intelligence, adequate memory, the ability to communicate, an awareness of the difference between truth and falsehood, and an appreciation of the obligation to tell the truth."

And, "The burden of proof rests on the party challenging the child's capacity to testify."

The former statement here supports all of the points mentioned in (A), and the latter statement shows again that someone needs to challenge the child's ability to testify – which isn't mentioned in the question.

I then found the same information (just worded differently) on another website. The process of establishing that the child is competent was also described – the judge gently presents basic questions the child, to determine a base level of intelligence and communication skills, and the ability to recall events and distinguish between truth and lies.

At this point, it was clear that (B) is the incorrect answer, as no "compelling evidence" is needed. I set my probability at 100/0, and concluded my research early.

column16:
I decided to tackle this by parsing out each sentence and translating each part using the Lojban online dictionaries. I did this in a separate doc in another window, and I showed this doc in the video several times as I made progress.

I looked up the English definition of each Lojban word as it came in sentence (A), and added the words in translation below each sentence. Once I had translated (A), I looked up "ku" to complete my translation of (B).

"Ku" was difficult to apply to the sentence as I learned that it's a terminator/negator, but I wasn't sure whether it would apply to what came before or after it in the sentence.

In the meantime, I revisited the question and the AI's response, and further refined my parsed translation through use of another dictionary, the glossary, and a webpage on Lojban grammar.

I ended up with:

(A)	do | gleki | co'a | lo nu | ra | mo'u | jukpa
You | happy | became | event | they | end | cook

= you became happy when they finished cooking

(B) do | gleki | co'a | ku | mo'u | lo nu | ra | jukpa
You | happy | became | terminator/negator of desc. | end | event | they | cook

= you stopped being happy when they finished cooking ?
= you became happy when they stopped the event of finishing cooking?

I think for (B), the first translation would likely apply as "you became happy" is more of a description than "they finished cooking". So this would be incorrect. But even if the second translation is true, (A) appears to translate more directly and seems to make more sense.

I did spend some time trying to work out what indicated "as soon as", to get a perfect translation, but I ran out of time, and I was quite sure that (A) was correct.

I set my probability at 75/25 to reflect the fact that I still don't entirely understand "ku" or its application in (B).

column16:
I immediately decided to look up whether blood pressure (BP) should be the same in both arms. It turns out that it normally should be (a very slight variation is possible). So for me, this immediately discounts (A) as being the correct answer, but I still need to make sure that I totally understand the question at hand by confirming the definition of some words.

I looked up the brachial and radial pulses. Translation: the patient's pulse is weaker in his wrist and above the elbow crease in his left arm (but is normal in his right arm).

Clearly, his BP isn't going to be the same in both arms, then.

A bruit is a sound that resembles a heart murmur, and is heard over partially blocked blood vessels. Since it was heard over the area where his left subclavian artery would be (I checked), this indicates his subclavian artery is partially blocked. So, a stent will obviously be of help, as suggested in (B).

The AI's response mentioned Subclavian Steal Syndrome (SSS). I looked it up.

SSS:
- Affects the left side much more commonly than the right
- Occurs when the subclavian artery is blocked, causing reversed blood flow – which would explain the reduced left arm pulse and the arm feeling tired
o	Smoking is a risk factor – patient is a smoker
o	Symptoms include vertigo, dizziness, a difference in pulses between arms, and subclavian bruit – all of which the patient has
o	Another symptom is decreased BP in the affected arm – so (A) is even less likely to be true
o	And a treatment option for SSS is stenting of the subclavian artery, as suggested by (B).

If the patient does indeed have SSS, then (B) would certainly be true, and not (A). 

But even if SSS is a misdiagnosis on the AI's part, the evidence apart from this also seems to confirm that the correct answer can only be (B). I set my probability at 0/100 to reflect this.

column14: After my research: A (Yes, as it constitutes a declaration against interest.): 100%; B (Yes, as it is considered a statement made by a co-conspirator.): 0%
column16:
I firstly looked up the definition of a declaration against interest in US law. For this to apply, "First, the declarant must be unavailable as a witness." – ok, so this would apply to the late husband's statement, not the wife's testimony.

I then looked up the US law definition of a co-conspirator statement. It's clear now that both (A) and (B) pertain to the late husband's statement, and not the wife's testimony. 

Regarding a co-conspirator statement, it seems that this 

"must be a statement by a co-conspirator of a party during the course and in furtherance of the conspiracy."

But to my understanding, this statement wasn't made during the course of and in furtherance of the conspiracy. The conspiracy had already ended (the fire had consumed the yacht), and when he made his statement, he wasn't asking his wife to continue the conspiracy on his behalf.

I read on:

"To admit a co-conspirator’s statement under this rule, the following criteria must be met:

[1] Existence of a Conspiracy
o	The court must find that there was a conspiracy involving the declarant and the party against whom the statement is offered. This does not mean that the conspiracy must be proven beyond a reasonable doubt, but there must be sufficient evidence to demonstrate its existence.

[2] Statement Made During the Course of the Conspiracy
o	The statement must have been made while the conspiracy was ongoing. Statements made after the conspiracy has ended may not be admissible under this rule.

[3] Statement Made in Furtherance of the Conspiracy
o	The statement must be made to help achieve the goals of the conspiracy. Casual remarks about the conspiracy may not qualify."

These criteria are unlikely to be met, because (these are my thoughts):

[1] As the AI pointed out, it's not clear from the question that there is proof of the conspiracy alleged to have been committed.

[2] The conspiracy had ended when the statement was made (according to the question, it was made the day after the incident).

[3] The statement could not have been made to help further the goals of the conspiracy, because a) the wife wasn't being asked to further the conspiracy, and b) the statement was made "while in the presence of a nurse attending to him". 

By this point, I was 100% sure that (A) was the correct answer. I decided to do some further research just to confirm my findings. The LII website seemed to confirm two of the points, and a US govt website confirmed all three of them:

"the co-conspirator's exception allows a conspirator hearsay rule and the sixth amendment right to or acts performed in furtherance of a conspiracy and during its pendency, provided there exists independent proof to establish the conspiracy."

So, this could in no way be admitted as a statement made by a co-conspirator, although not solely for the reasoning that the AI suggested. I set my probability at 100/0 to reflect my certainty.
