The letter was between the father and the landlord about the rent, not between father and son about the allowance, which is what is being contested here.
column14: After my research: A (unsuccessful, as the agreement between the student and his father was not formalized in writing and signed by the paternal figure.): 45%; B (successful.): 55%
column16:
This was very difficult to research. I tried searching on "verbal contract death US law", as I assumed this would be treated as a verbal contract. Most of the results were about wills, but as this contract wasn't conditional on death, these results aren't relevant.

I then researched general validity of verbal contracts under US law. My thinking is that this is a verbal contract, and the student had accepted the terms and carried out his consideration by not marrying. The letter from the father to the landlord, and the payment of the tuition fees, do also show that the father had agreed to provide financial assistance to his son, although they don't prove that he had promised the $200 monthly allowance. The payment of tuition fees could be considered the father fulfilling consideration on his part, however, making the contract valid.

The LII page on verbal contracts states that they are valid, unless they fail under UCC (which won't apply in this case as it's not a commercial transaction), or the statutes of fraud in each state. A state isn't mentioned in the question, so I assume anything at state level doesn't apply. Therefore, I assume this verbal contract is valid.

I did note that the LII page used the term "verbal agreement", so I tried to look up the difference between a verbal agreement and verbal contract under US law, but all the results generated just discussed verbal contracts.

I then decided to look up contract validity upon death, since if this is a valid contract, it should follow the usual rules.

According to LexisNexis: 

“The general rule is that the death of one of the parties to a contract does not discharge the contract. Where the contract is of a personal nature then, unless there has been a breach of the contract prior to the death, the general rule does not apply.”

I wasn't sure how to read this. Generally, the contract is still valid upon death. Unless it's a personal contract (which I assume this is). Unless the personal contract has been breached prior to death – it hasn't, unless we count the fact that the father didn't transfer money on the 25th of January when he didn't hear from the landlord. So if we apply the double-negative, a breach would make the personal contract valid again upon death...? This didn't make sense.

I then read on:

“The second thing that you should understand is that in most instances there is a presumption in the law that a contract will survive the death of the person obligated by the contract.”

So it seems more likely than not that the father (or his estate) would still be bound by the (verbal) contract.

With time almost up, I re-read the question and possible answers, as well as the AI's reasoning. 

The reasoning in (A) for the son being unsuccessful would hinge on the fact that the contract was not in writing and signed by the father. Although I haven't proven that this would count as a verbal contract and therefore be valid, if it is a verbal contract, then there's no need for it to be in writing. 

I chose (B) as my final answer because, according to my research, it seemed that if the student were to be unsuccessful, it would be due to his father's death making the contract invalid, rather than it not being in writing. However, this was difficult to research and I'm not confident that this is correct, so I set my probability at 45/55.

column10: After reading the AI's answer: A (Denied, as it is considered hearsay and does not fall within any recognized exceptions.): 25%; B (Admitted and considered as valid evidence of the womanâ€™s state of intoxication at the time of the incident.): 75%

column14: After my research: A (Denied, as it is considered hearsay and does not fall within any recognized exceptions.): 0%; B (Admitted and considered as valid evidence of the womanâ€™s state of intoxication at the time of the incident.): 100%
column16:
I immediately looked up US hearsay exceptions. From what I read, I'm not even sure that a court record counts as hearsay (this backs up the AI's first point):

“for verbal or nonverbal conduct to fall within the definition of the hearsay rule as defined under the federal rules of evidence, it must be either an expressly assertive written or spoken utterance, or nonverbal conduct expressly intended to be an assertion.”

I searched directly on whether court records are considered hearsay. Prior court decisions fall under the "matter of record" exception, and may be admitted as evidence.

"The third exception to the hearsay rule is the "matter of record" exception. This exception allows for official government records, private business records, prior court decisions or documents, and prior testimony of an unavailable witness to be admitted as evidence."

I feel very confident already that (B) is correct. The woman had already pled guilty in court to the charge of driving while intoxicated in relation to the accident in question. She was fined, which shows that the judge agreed she was guilty. And this is an authenticated court record of her conviction. I can't see any reason as to why it wouldn't be accepted as evidence of her state of intoxication at the time of the incident.

I then searched on hearsay in a civil court to see whether this made a difference, but the application of the rule appears to be the same.

I went back to one of the LII pages on hearsay, and read this exception to Rule 803 Exceptions to the Rule Against Hearsay: 

"(22) Judgment of a Previous Conviction. Evidence of a final judgment of conviction if:

o	(A) the judgment was entered after a trial or guilty plea, but not a nolo contendere plea;

o	(B) the conviction was for a crime punishable by death or by imprisonment for more than a year;

o	(C) the evidence is admitted to prove any fact essential to the judgment; and

o	(D) when offered by the prosecutor in a criminal case for a purpose other than impeachment, the judgment was against the defendant."

The verified record of the prior court judgement meets all of these criteria. The woman pled guilty, the crime was punishable by up to 2 years imprisonment (although she didn't get that, the evidence is relevant and essential to the judgement, and the judgement was against the current defendant.

I'm now 100% certain that (B) is correct. I still have research time, so I quickly look up what else might make evidence inadmissible, but then realise that the wording in (A) gives hearsay as the reason for its inadmission, so any other reasoning would be irrelevant.

I set my probability at 0/100 and concluded my research early.

column16:
I first look up US contract terms, for a refresher. But, I'm already aware (and the AI already concurred) that:

- There’s a letter where the uncle offers consideration and the timeline for the transfer
- The nephew responded with his agreement in writing
- And the owner had agreed to the lease transfer

I don't really feel I need to research this, to be honest.

The LII webpage states that a contract needs the following:

o	Offer and acceptance (yes, we have both in writing)
o	Consideration (yes – the shop and the $150k)
o	Capacity (yes  – there's no mention of uncle being not of sound mind, and this isn’t part of either answer anyway)
o	Legality (yes, there's no mention of the agreement not being in accordance with the law)

Again, it seems that the pair already had a contract before the uncle instructed his lawyer to write one up.

I then looked up US contract stipulations, in case I found anything about how a contract stipulation can't be outside either party's influence. It appears that the stipulation about the owner's agreement is a type of stipulation called a proviso, which is a clause in a contract that requires that something must occur before the agreement can be valid. But in this case, the proviso of the owner agreeing to the lease transfer did happen, so that's all fine.

I looked further into provisos, and could not find anything about them being within or without the relevant parties' direct influence.

I then looked up some proviso examples, and found one on a legal website that appeared to be outside of either stakeholder's direct influence.

Then, on re-reading the possible answers, I realised that I had been looking at this the wrong way round anyway, since (B) is still a "yes, he was successful" answer. Still, I haven't found anything about how a proviso being outside of the parties' direct influence is a "good", validating thing.

I'm now certain that the answer is (A) – they had definitely already formed a contract, and the lawyer was simply drafting up documentation of this. I set my probability at 100/0 to reflect this.

column16:
I firstly looked up peripheral artery disease (PAD), on the NHS website.

I found that several of the patient's symptoms match a PAD diagnosis (leg ache when walking that goes away when resting, both legs being affected at once but the pain being worse in one leg, and ulcers on the foot that don't heal).

I also found that he meets most of the listed causes of PAD: 

o	smoking – the most significant risk factor - yes
o	type 1 diabetes and type 2 diabetes - yes
o	high blood pressure (hypertension) - yes
o	high cholesterol - no
o	growing older – yes

I then looked up the patient's other symptoms. His pulse isn't palpable on the right foot, indicating impaired blood flow. The nocturnal toe pain didn't come up (yet), but his ankle-brachial index scores do further indicate a PAD diagnosis.

I then read that "Angiography of the lower extremities is most often used to diagnose PAD", which supports answer (A).

I then decided to disprove (B) by looking up indications of infected ulcers.

From the Cleveland Clinic website, drainage from the ulcer would indicate an infection, but it's mentioned that there is no pus. The description on this website of an arterial ulcer matches the description of what the patient has. An arterial ulcer is a symptom of PAD.

I then read:

"If you have an infection or experience irritation, you might see swelling and redness around the base of the ulcer. The redness often turns to a pale white or yellow color if you elevate your leg. Arterial ulcers are typically very painful, especially at night."

So it's not infected from the description, but this being an arterial ulcer would explain the night-time pain in his toe.

While antibiotics is listed as a possible treatment option, there is no indication that the ulcer is infected. And in any case, from what I've found, antibiotic treatment would simply be treating a symptom while ignoring the cause – as the AI also stated.

I am now 100% sure that (A) is the correct answer.

column14: After my research: A (ma cfagau lo fagri): 100%; B (ma cfari lo fagri): 0%
column16:
I decided to look up each word in the Lojban-English dictionary, to confirm the AI's translation.

"Ma" does indeed mean what/who/how/why – the dictionary definition states that here, we fill in the appropriate sumti blank. So, it could mean "what" or "who" according to the context of the rest of the sentence.

"Lo fagri" does translate as "the fire".

"Cfari" means starts/commences/begins to occur/initiate.

"Cfagau" means a "person/agent" "initiates/begins/starts/causes the beginning of" – this is indeed a compound word, as the AI suggests.

I already believe I can take the AI at its word, but I decided to look up how sumti questions work with "ma", to further prove that the AI is correct.

According to the Lojban grammar webpage I visited, "ma" can indeed be used to indicate "what" or "who" (etc) depending on sumti (context/subject). 

I decided to parse out each sentence and translate, according to what I had found in the dictionary and grammar webpage:

ma | cfagau | lo fagri 
what | person started | the fire?

ma | cfari | lo fagri 
what | started | the fire?

It's clear that (A) is the correct answer. I set my probability at 100/0 and concluded my research early.

column16:
I immediately went to look up US law Rule 404, since this is what the AI cited.

It immediately became clear that what the AI stated was correct:

"Rule 404. Character Evidence; Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts

-	(b) Other Crimes, Wrongs, or Acts.
-	(1) Prohibited Uses. Evidence of any other crime, wrong, or act is not admissible to prove a person’s character in order to show that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character.
-	(2) Permitted Uses. This evidence may be admissible for another purpose, such as proving motive, opportunity, intent, preparation, plan, knowledge, identity, absence of mistake, or lack of accident."

So, it's true that evidence of a previous crime would not be admissible in order to prove a person's character, or to show that they had likely acted within that character. This is the reasoning given in (A) – "Yes, to demonstrate the defendant's inclination to engage in such criminal activity." According to Rule 404, this would not be permitted, as to demonstrate their inclination to commit such a crime, we'd need to establish that it is in their character to do so.

It is also true that evidence of other crimes is permissible in order to prove "absence of mistake". I then decided to look up "absence of mistake" within US law, to see whether the accountant's defence would fall under this description.

I found another LII page discussing the MIMIC rule (relating to the previously mentioned Rule 404). It provided the same information, but I followed a hyperlink through to the US legal definition of a "mistake". 

"In criminal law, a mistake can serve as a defense that claims either a misconception of the law or a mistake of some fact."

Following the hyperlink through to the definition of "mistake of fact", I found that the accountant's defence would indeed fall under this category:

"A mistake of fact is a mistake about a material factual element or mistaken belief other than a mistake of law." 

– yes, the defence of "confusion over the payment date" would meet this definition.

"The Model Penal Code §2.04 provides that “ignorance or mistake as to a matter of fact or law is a defense if: the ignorance or mistake negatives the purpose, knowledge, belief, recklessness or negligence required to establish a material element of the offense; or the law provides that the state of mind established by such ignorance or mistake constitutes a defense.”"

– yes, using this mistake of fact as a defence would negate the recklessness/purpose required to commit the alleged fraud.

At this point I am certain that (B) is correct, since it has been proven as possible, and (A) has been disproven.

I re-read the question and answer, and a couple of the webpages again to be certain, before setting my probability at 0/100.

column16:
I firstly looked up what a venous duplex scan entails, as I thought this was the most likely diagnostic option given the AI's response.

What I read wasn't helpful (yet), so I decided to research the patient's vital readings. All of his readings were normal, apart from an elevated blood pressure.

I then looked up his swollen leg symptoms/description. The initial NHS results were too generic, so I looked up DVT, as this is what the AI suggested the patient may have.

According to the symptoms listed by the NHS, he matches the description of having single-limb swelling with warm skin. He also has the risk factor of having cancer, and the NHS states that if DVT is suspected, the patient will be referred for a diagnostic ultrasound scan. When I looked up "venous duplex scan" earlier, I learned that it was a type of ultrasound scan.

I then looked into DVT diagnostics and venous duplex, and confirmed that it is indeed the most likely diagnostic test used for suspected DVT.

I then looked up the other suggested answer, lower extremity CT angiogram.

I quickly learned that this is used for diagnosing PAD. From what I remember of my research for the earlier question on PAD, the symptoms that this patient has don't match. However, I looked up PAD symptoms to confirm this. It appears that if the patient had PAD, his legs would more likely feel cool to the touch, there wouldn't necessarily be swelling, there'd be other, more notable symptoms, and he would have a weak or absent pulse in his leg. According to the question, he has pulses on both sides of his leg.

I also then did some more reading, and decided to confirm that (as I suspect) PAD symptoms are slower onset (yes), and DVT symptoms are faster onset, as this patient has experienced (also yes).

At this point, I'm confident that I have proved (A) is true as much as possible, and I have also disproved (B) as much as possible. I set my probability at 95/5, as I did follow the AI's suggestion of DVT and didn't go down the route of trying to check every other possible diagnosis with the presented symptoms (if this is even possible!).

column14: After my research: A (Validate it, given that the right against self-incrimination is applicable in both civil and criminal proceedings.): 70%; B (Disallow it, on the grounds that the woman relinquished this right by choosing to testify voluntarily.): 30%
column16:
I firstly looked up “US court right to remain silent when testifying”. According to the LII website:

"A witness may "plead the Fifth" and not answer if the witness believes answering the question may be self-incriminatory."

I then followed a hyperlink through to the page on self-incrimination. On reading the definition, I considered whether this would apply to this witness. 

"Self-incrimination is the intentional or unintentional act of providing information that will suggest your involvement in a crime, or expose you to criminal prosecution."

then:

"But it may extend to a witness in any proceeding if their testimony provides a reasonable possibility of incriminating oneself in future criminal proceedings, even if the testimony is made in a civil procedure."

I think this comes down to whether the witness' alleged intoxicating drug use referred to a criminalised drug, and we don't know this. 

If it referred to marijuana use in certain states, she may have wanted to remain silent simply so that her testimony wouldn't appear unreliable, as the AI had pointed out. In this case she would not be allowed to plead the fifth, as there would be no fear of future criminal proceedings.

If she had used illegal drugs, then she would have likely been refusing to answer in order to avoid self-incrimination, which could lead to prosecution later. In this case, she would be permitted to plead the fifth.

Without knowing the type of drug (and possibly the state), I'm not sure whether it's possible to answer this one accurately!

I decided that it was more likely than not that the drug in question was illegal, given how few intoxicating drugs are legalised in the US, and then only in selected states.

I searched on, to confirm that the right to remain silent would apply to witnesses in civil trials, and that they would be permitted to selectively answer questions. I firstly found content referring to how this is applicable to criminal cases, but eventually found some text on the Greenspunlaw website that confirms that it applies to witnesses in civil cases also:

"Witnesses and defendants may be able to plead the Fifth in these situations: Criminal proceedings, Civil lawsuits..."

"Self-incriminating. In order to be considered self-incriminating, the statements sought to be compelled must be such that it may lead to criminal prosecution or lead to other evidence that will be used for this purpose. This includes information that provides links in the chain towards a possible prosecution of the individual."

And

"… if the prosecution can make use of the answer itself or any evidence it might lead to, the witness is entitled to claim the privilege against self-incrimination."

Assuming the witness used illegal drugs, I believe that the right to remain silent while testifying as a witness in a civil case would apply. Therefore, the correct answer would be (A).

I set my probability at 70/30 due to the uncertainty over whether the drug use would be incriminating. 

Note: And I now think I'm incorrect, as I realised that the woman would be the plaintiff, not a witness. Doh!

column14: After my research: A (Certainly, the judge has the authority to take into account hearsay while deciding on preliminary issues.): 80%; B (Certainly not, as it constitutes hearsay which does not fall under any recognized exception.): 20%
column16:
I firstly looked up "US hearsay dying exception", as this is where the AI focused.

The LII website confirmed that a dying declaration is a statement made by declarant under belief of impending death, and that while it’s hearsay, it counts as an exception to the hearsay rule, listed in Section 804(b)(2) of Federal Rules of Evidence.

I then followed the hyperlink to Section 804(b)(2):

"(2) Statement Under the Belief of Imminent Death. In a prosecution for homicide or in a civil case, a statement that the declarant, while believing the declarant’s death to be imminent, made about its cause or circumstances."

This confirms that the dying declaration would be a hearsay exception (as the patient believed he was dying and the statement was about his cause of death), if the doctor's affidavit is admissible to provide that necessary context. 

I looked up "affidavit" to clarify the meaning – it's a sworn statement made out of court, where the person asserts that certain facts are true (or they are true to the best of their knowledge).

Ok, so it's been determined that the patient's statement would be admissible, but would the doctor's – which is needed to admit the original statement?

I looked up general hearsay exceptions, but nothing here jumped out.

I then looked up whether an affidavit is generally admissible in US court. I read that it generally isn't admissible at trial as it's considered hearsay, but then this was a personal injury law website, and they may have been playing this up for their own benefit. I know by now that there are plenty of exceptions to hearsay.

I then read in a post on Law StackExchange:

"An affidavit is not admissible evidence in court unless a specific exception to the hearsay rule applies."

Not too helpful, but confirms an affidavit is treated the same as all general hearsay.

I went back to re-read the answers. (A) states that the judge can consider hearsay when determining "preliminary issues." I looked up preliminary issues.

"A “preliminary issue” is a discrete element of a dispute that has the potential to decisively conclude the claim..."

So, it's an element of dispute that would influence how the trial goes. This certainly seems to apply to the doctor's statement, as if it can be used to prove the patient's statement was a dying declaration, the patient's statement against the driver could be taken into account.

I then read on the LII website: 

"Rule 104: Preliminary Questions
o	(a) In General. The court must decide any preliminary question about whether a witness is qualified, a privilege exists, or evidence is admissible. In so deciding, the court is not bound by evidence rules, except those on privilege."

If the court is not bound by evidence rules, I assume this means the judge can take hearsay into account.

Other quotations on the page (I'm not sure whether they were law or just arguments) appeared to back up the assertion that the judge can take into account hearsay and affidavits when deciding on preliminary questions. 

I then confirmed with another legal website:

"The Rules provide that preliminary questions concerning:  ... (c) admissibility of evidence, must be determined by the court outside the presence of the jury. Federal Rule of Evidence 104. The rules of evidence do not apply to such proceedings, thus hearsay is admissible."

So it appears that the doctor’s statement would be admissible in establishing the preliminary question of the admissibility of the patient's statement, since hearsay/affidavits are admissible at this stage in proceedings. The AI is correct, although not exactly for the reasons that it stated.

I selected (A) as the correct answer, and set my probability at 80/20 as while I'm quite certain, the multiple layers of this one made it tricky, and my reasoning does not match that of the AI.

column16: After doing some research I found out that the doctor was actually assessing the Supraspinatous muscle. On Stanford Medicine website, it clearly shows images on how both Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus tests are done. For a Supraspinatus Test, the patient is asked to abduct both arms to 90° and then to bring them anteriorly with a 30° forward flexion. The patient is also asked to bring both thumbs down in this position. On the other hand, the Infraspinatus test is done by asking the patient to flex the forearms at 90° with the palms supinated.

If the client didn't want the lawyer to offer the service, they could have indicated on the note.

column16:
Research shows that even though the co-passenger's statement is hearsay, it's against interest and an exception to the rule on hearsay. The co-passenger's statement may be used, where generally the content of the statement is so prejudicial to them making it that they would not have made the statement unless they believed the statement was true. 

Under the Federal Rules of Evidence, Rule 804(b)(3) provides:

"A statement that:

- a reasonable person in the declarant's position would have made only if the person believed it to be true because, when made, it was so contrary to the declarant's proprietary or pecuniary interest or had so great a tendency to invalidate the declarant's claim against someone else or to expose the declarant to civil or criminal liability. (Wikipedia)

column16: Hearsay, in a legal forum, is an out-of-court statement which is being offered in court for the truth of what was asserted. The statement made by the officer falls under 'excited utterance', which is a statement made by a person in response to a startling or shocking event or condition. It is an exception to the hearsay rule since the statement must be spontaneously made by the person while still under the stress of excitement from the event or condition. This makes answer A correct. However, answer B is also correct in the sense that the testimony provided may be potential to prejudice which may seem unfair to the accused person. It's upon the judge to decide the best way forward.

column16: Contractual obligations are the contract terms that all parties commit to. These can be the delivery, timelines and due dates, payment terms, performance and quality, termination, and more. They are all legally binding. A contract can be altered in any way as long as it's mentioned in the actual contract. Given that we don't know if the contract states that any alterations must be put in writing, we can not say for sure that answer A is correct. However, answer B states that there was no consideration provided. This is not correct. Consideration in the US law is the price one pays for another's promise. In this case, the construction company had already done it's part and the property owner already agreed to relieve the company of it's duty to install the pavement.

So, the bank was unable to withdraw its offer once the customer had initiated performance.

column16: A witness can only invoke the Right to Remain Silent privilege in response to a specific question that may incriminate oneself if they answer that question. However, a defendant has a right to confrontation provided by the Sixth Amendment. If the invocation may prevent adequate cross-examination, it may not be invoked. The privilege usually applies in criminal procedure. But it may extend to a witness in any proceeding if their testimony provides a reasonable possibility of incriminating oneself in future criminal proceedings, even if the testimony is made in a civil procedure. However, if the civil records are maintained for administrative purposes as public records, the privilege does not apply. In this case, since the defendant has the right to get the answer regarding her intoxication, the woman will probably be forced to answer it. Even though answer A may also apply, it's more likely that the woman relinquished the right to remain silent by choosing to testify voluntarily.

column16: Under Federal law, a statement made by a co-conspirator during and to further the conspiracy is admissible as evidence, but there must be other evidence establishing both the conspiracy and the defendant's participation. In this case, the insurance company doesn't have any evidence to further the claims of conspiracy or the involvement of the friend in the whole situation. The court must also find that there was a conspiracy involving the declarant and the party against whom the statement is offered. All these eliminate answer B. So, the testimony can be used as a declaration against interest. This is when someone says something that goes against their own interests. It's allowed because people usually don't say things that hurt themselves unless they're true. To use this kind of evidence, the person who said it has to be unavailable to testify, and the statement has to hurt their own case or help the other side's case.

column16: No minimum age exists for children's testimony. In making decisions about children, some States follow the approach of Rule 601 of the Federal Rules of Evidence, which states that every person is competent to be a witness. Other State laws provide that children are incompetent unless they understand the nature of an oath. Still other States hold that children below certain ages, usually 10, 12, or 14, are presumptively incompetent unless determined otherwise. Nevertheless, a voir dire examination is usually held to determine whether a child is competent. The trial judge has substantial discretion regarding the conduct of this examination. This is a statement from the US Department of Justice. It's important to not assume that there exists a sufficient ground to believe that the child, despite his tender age and traumatic experience, possesses personal knowledge of the incident and comprehends the importance of delivering a truthful account in the court of law. So, it's important for the prosecution attorney to initially present compelling evidence.

column16: The Jobe (or empty can) test has the patient hold their arm in 90 degrees of abduction, 30 degrees of forward flexion, and resist a downward force while in the thumbs down position. Pain and/or weakness in this position may indicate supraspinatus pathology. A study in 2011 used electromyography to study the levels of activity in the shoulder muscles during flexion, and found that supraspinatus was consistently recruited prior to movement of the limb at all loads; the authors concluded that "Posterior rotator cuff muscles appear to be counterbalancing anterior translational forces produced during flexion and it would appear that supraspinatus is one of the muscles that consistently 'initiates' flexion.

column16: According to FRE 608(b), extrinsic evidence is not admissible to prove specific instances of a witness's conduct in order to attack or support the witness's character for truthfulness. This means the respondent can try to challenge the expert witness's credibility by asking them about their previous false testimony during cross-examination. However, they can only ask questions about it and can't use outside evidence to prove it.

column16: I looked up what constitutes a legally binding contract under US law to be able to affirm my choice. I confirmed that a contract does not need to be in writing to be legally enforceable in the US. I also confirmed that you can make changes to a contract before it has been signed. In fact, it's pretty easy and isn’t technically an amendment at all – it’s just part of negotiating the terms, or redlining. If there is a mutual understanding that the contract would only be binding when reduced to writing and signed by both parties, then either party can change their mind before the final written contract is executed.

column16: This was a very dicey one as i couldn't get enough confirmation to back my decision to go with the AI's choice. However, Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of whatever it asserts, which is then offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter. The problem with hearsay is that when the person being quoted is not present, it becomes impossible to establish credibility it is generally inadmissible unless an exception applies. There are a number of exceptions to the hearsay rule (including present-sense impression, excited utterances, declarations of present state of mind, dying and the business records exceptions), as well as things defined not to be hearsay (admission of a party-opponent, and prior statements of a witness).

column16: Looking at the definition of hearsay: any oral or written statements made by a person who is not testifying in court but those statements are relied upon to prove that which is contained in them. The following are the most common hearsay exceptions that you might encounter: Admission by the other party (known as “admission by a party-opponent” or “admission against interest”): Statements made by the other party that can be used against him/her will often qualify under this hearsay exception.

column16: Judging from the lack of pain and zero history of trauma, the obvious bet is to wait and watch. I still followed the AI's guidelines to confirm my choice and found out that a varicocele usually occurs on the left side of the scrotum and often produces no signs or symptoms. Possible signs and symptoms may include: Pain. A dull, aching pain or discomfort is more likely when standing or late in the day. I also checked that Varicoceles occur in around 15% to 20% of all men, and around 40% of males who are evaluated as infertile, will also have it. While varicoceles can appear on the left or right side of the scrotum, it's quite rare for it to occur on the right. Varicoceles can cause three main problems: Impaired fertility, decreased testosterone production by the testis, or scrotal discomfort. Abdominal ultrasound and abdominal CT are useful in the differential diagnosis of primary and secondary varicocele. Risks of CT scans include: Allergy to contrast dye. Exposure to radiation. Damage to kidney function from contrast dye.

column16: After going through my research, i want to say that my final answer is choice B. Salespeople must receive a written copy of the commission contract separate from any other employment contract. There are no federal laws regarding the payment of commissions following termination of employment. In the case of this employee, he didn't sign any commission contract and as such he can't challenge his employer. Under the laws of the United States, there are no minimum requirements for an employment contract. Also, in most states, no written memorialisation of any terms is required. An employment relationship in the United States is presumed to be “at-will,” i.e., terminable by either party, with or without cause or notice. The worker will most likely be able to collect unpaid sales commissions after they have been terminated if they can prove the claims cited in their case and win the lawsuit. Unpaid sales commissions may be issued to workers who prevail on such lawsuits as one of several legal remedies.

column16: I started my research by following the AI's guidelines. The Parkland formula, also known as Baxter formula, is a burn formula developed by Charles R. Baxter, used to estimate the amount of replacement fluid required for the first 24 hours in a burn patient so as to ensure the patient is hemodynamically stable. Circumferential full-thickness burns with resultant loss of skin elasticity can produce a tourniquet effect on limbs and trunk, which can lead to compromised distal perfusion, airway obstruction, and poor respiratory effort. PVCs rarely cause problems unless they occur again and again over a long period of time. In such cases, they can lead to a PVC-induced cardiomyopathy, or a weakening of the heart muscle from too many PVCs. This response, along with decreased cardiac output and increased vascular resistance, can lead to marked hypovolemia and hypoperfusion called “burn shock.” This can be managed with aggressive fluid resuscitation and close monitoring for adequate, but not excessive, IV fluids.

column16: Subclavian steal syndrome (SSS), now termed subclavian-vertebral artery steal syndrome, refers to the diversion of blood flow away from its normal target and the arm. These symptoms are secondary to upper extremity ischemia during vigorous exercise. It can also present as a variety of neurological symptoms secondary to vertebrobasilar insufficiency. These symptoms include dizziness, blurring of vision, syncope, vertigo, disequilibrium, ataxia, tinnitus, or hearing loss. Ninety-four percent of patients with subclavian steal have a systolic blood pressure that is 20 mm Hg or more lower on the affected side compared to the opposite arm (the mean difference between the arms is 45 mm Hg in affected patients). Conservative treatment is usually the best initial therapy, with surgery reserved for refractory symptomatic cases. Percutaneous angioplasty and stenting, rather than bypass grafts of the subclavian artery, is the usual favoured surgical approach.

column16: I started off by verifying the Lojban word order: A Lojban sentence expresses a relationship (bridi), normally claiming that the relationship holds (that it is 'true'). A bridi relationship consists of several ideas or objects called arguments (sumti), which are related by a predicate relation (selbri). The following uses the Lojban terms bridi, sumti, and selbri, because it is best to come to understand them independent of the English associations of the corresponding words. column16: Following the AI's guidelines, i researched what the legal requirements for a statement to be considered a declaration against interest under United States law and i can see that a declaration against interest differs from a party admission because here the declarant does not have to be a party to the case but must have a basis for knowing that the statement is true. Furthermore, evidence of the statement will only be admissible if the declarant is unavailable to testify. Whether under the Federal Rules or not, declarations of co-conspirators are admissible against the defendant only if three elements are satisfied: 1) the statement was made in furtherance of the conspiracy 2) it was made during the course of the conspiracy and 3) there is independent evidence to establish the conspiracy.

column16: The typical symptoms of SBO includes Crampy abdominal pain that comes and goes, Loss of appetite, Constipation, Vomiting, Inability to have a bowel movement or pass gas, Swelling of the abdomen. The common causes of SBO in patients with no known history of hernias were categorized as small bowel neoplasms (benign and malignant), adhesions, stricture or inflammation, intussusceptions, foreign bodies, internal hernia, mesenteric volvulus, and other special causes. The initial management for a patient diagnosed with SBO  includes intravenous fluid resuscitation with correction of metabolic derangements, nasogastric decompression, and bowel rest. Nasogastric decompression improves patient comfort, minimizes or prevents recurrent vomiting, and serves as a means to monitor the progress or resolution of these conditions.

column16: Infrared technology and imaging systems are already used extensively by the law enforcement (LE) community, typically to gain a tactical advantage or obtain immediate situational awareness. As the use of infrared technology becomes more affordable and widespread, LE is finding new ways to use it and leverage the results in the courtroom as evidence.  Kyllo v. United States, 533 U.S. 27 (2001), was a decision by the Supreme Court of the United States in which the court ruled that the use of thermal imaging devices to monitor heat radiation in or around a person's home, even if conducted from a public vantage point, is unconstitutional without a search warrant. In its majority opinion, the court held that thermal imaging constitutes a "search" under the Fourth Amendment, as the police were using devices to "explore details of the home that would previously have been unknowable without physical intrusion." The ruling has been noted for refining the reasonable expectation of privacy doctrine in light of new surveillance technologies, and when those are used in areas that are accessible to the public. Infrared thermal imaging, also called infrared imaging or thermal imaging, allows us to see how people are using space in ways we couldn’t before and often can’t with traditional camera monitoring. It’s a powerful tool for planning building layouts and doing people movement studies. I decided to go with choice B because the photographs had already been certified by a specialist who vetted the accuracy and reliability of infrared imaging.

column16: The Fifth Amendment creates a number of rights relevant to both criminal and civil legal proceedings. In criminal cases, the Fifth Amendment guarantees the right to a grand jury, forbids “double jeopardy,” and protects against self-incrimination. Yes a witness who has decided to testify has the right to refuse to answer specific questions, especially if those questions might incriminate them. This right is protected by the Fifth Amendment, which guards against self-incrimination. In civil cases, questions posed to witnesses should be relevant to the issues being litigated. Irrelevant questions might be objected to and excluded by the court based on evidentiary rules. Filing a lawsuit and voluntarily testifying in a civil case does not entirely waive a person's Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, but it can restrict the extent of that right in specific situations.

I chose A as my final answer after researching because as per the definition of hearsay, it may not be admissible in court, however there are exceptions when hearsay can be admissible in court.
The security officer falls under these exceptions since he did not participate in the civil court proceedings and therefore the plaintiff’s estates evidence is permissible because of the following:
1.	Federal Rule of Evidence 804 deals with exceptions to the hearsay rule for unavailable declarants. It provides a framework for admitting certain hearsay statements when the person who made the statement (the declarant) is unavailable to testify in court. Over here the declarant is the security personnel.
2.	Federal Rule 804(b) outlines specific exceptions to the hearsay rule for statements made by an unavailable declarant, which include former testimony thus statements made by the declarant in a previous trial or proceeding that are now offered as evidence in a different case. Due to this, law the evidence is permissible. 
When I initially chose B, I was not aware of these Federal rule of evidence.

I chose A as my final answer after researching what a dying declaration is and can a hearsay from a deceased person be used in the US court of law.
In the rule of law, hearsay, which is an out-of-court statement cannot be admissible in court as evidence. However, in my research, I found out that there is an exception in the hearsay rule. 
In a homicide or civil case, a declaration of a dying person while at the time of making the statement believed they were impending, or imminent death can be admissible in court. If the statement was made about their cause of death or circumstance, this can be an exception.
This rule can be found in the Federal Rule 804 (b) (2) under Exceptions of hearsay.

column16:
I chose B as my final answer after researching what a unilateral contract is online.
A unilateral contract is a contract where by one party the offeror makes an offer or a promise in exchange for the performance of an act by the other party know as an offeree. 
In order to accept a unilateral contract, the offeree must perform the specific act but it’s not enough for the offeree to begin to perform, they must complete the required performance.
In this situation the offeror is the bank, and the offeree is the customer. The customer joined the queue while the promotional sign was up, and this indicates he has stated performing the specific act on the promotional sign. Now the customer kept track of the time and even though the promotional sign was changed later. Even though, the new sign stated the promotion was discontinued, he was still in the queue for more than 5 minutes which means he has completed the task or act that was on the promotional sign, and therefore deserves to be rewarded for that.
Now regarding the bank changing the promotional sign and discontinuing the promotion, this does not affect the customer as they have already started performing the act.
As per research regarding revoking a unilateral contract, an offeror can revoke their unilateral contact at any time before performance starts. Also, the offeror can’t revoke a unilateral contract once the offeree starts a physical performance of the contract which is what the customer did before the promotional sign was changed.
In conclusion, after researching and putting together all the new information I found, I think choice B is the final answer.

column16:
I chose A as my final answer after doing some research online.
From the statement, it can be inferred or deduced that the possible agreement between the lawyer and the client is an implied-in-fact contract.
An implied-in-fact contract is formed between two parties based on actions, behaviors, conduct or circumstances of the involved parties, rather than through written or verbal consent.
An example of such a contract is, when you walk into a hair salon and sit in a chair for a haircut. If the barber cuts your hair, thus provides you a service, you are obliged to pay him or her for the service provided even though there was no written or verbal agreement.
In the statement, the lawyer found a paper in his office with a legal question from a customer who he has completed a task for recently. Now he went ahead to provide answer or response to the question and sent it back the customer with an invoice.
Now since he acted on the request from former client, by providing legal advice in a response which he had sent to her, this definitely falls under an implied-in-fact contract. 
Therefore, the client has no choice but to pay the lawyer even though she stated that she did not go ahead to sell her yacht and therefore did not require the response.
From the deduction above, I concluded my final answer as A.

When a contract is voidable, one of the parties in a contract is able to cancel the contract due to one of the following reasons, mistake, lack of capacity, undue influence, misrepresentation and fraud and if a person is a minor.

In the case, this contract is voidable by lack of capacity. A person who lacks mental capacity can void or have their guardian void a contract.
Since the senior citizen was hospitalized and was on potent painkillers after she was discharged, she would have not been in a very sound mind when she sold her car to her neighbor for a fee below the market value of $450.

column16:
I chose A as my final answer after doing some research.
We have to first look at the definition of admission against interest. An admission against interest is as an out-of-court statement made by a party that is against their own pecuniary, proprietary, or penal interest, and that is admissible under both an exclusion (admission by a party-opponent) and an exception (statement against interest) to the rule against hearsay. 
The general rule against hearsay prevents out of court statements being used in court because these statements may be untrustworthy. However, there are exceptions to the hearsay rule which allow for a declaration against interest under the reasoning that a person would rarely say something that would be against their interests unless it were true. 
In this case, the deceased friend, knowing he would pass away soon, confessed receiving a payment and his involvement in the crime to his wife. 
Even though the statement he made to his wife is out of court and falls under the hearsay rules, it can fall under the exceptions of hearsay under admission against interest. Therefore, the statement he made to his wife can be used in court.
The following information led me to choose A as my final answer

I chose A as my final answer after doing some researching.
First of all double bubble sign or Duodenal atresia is a condition in newborn babies where there is an intestinal obstruction or closure in their small intestines. This prevents the passage of milk and digestive fluids. Some of the symptoms of low birth weight, vomiting, and swelling in the upper abdomen.
This condition requires a surgery to repair it.
Diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema is a condition in newborn babies where air gets trapped in the tissues outside of tiny air sacs (alveoli) in the lungs. It occurs when the lungs do not make enough surfactant which allows the alveoli to be more flexible and prevents them from breaking.
Some of the symptoms include fast breathing, grunting and parts of the babies body tinted blue(cyanosis) due to low oxygen in the blood.

Looking at the symptoms and the condition of the newborn, they are very similar to the symptoms of diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema, there if can be deduced that the newborn may be suffering from diffuse pulmonary interstitial edema 
Hence my final answer was A.

I chose B as my final answer after doing some research.
From my research, evidence from prior convictions may be admitted under Federal Rule of Evidence 609 which governs the admissibility of evidence for impeachment purposes.
According to Rule 609, past convictions may be admitted in impeaching a witness or the defendant under the following conditions:
1.	The crime was punishable by death or a prison sentence of greater than 1 year.
2.	The crime involved fraud or dishonesty.
If a crime involves dishonesty or is more recent, it is more likely that the criminal conviction will be admissible for impeachment.
Also in the trial, the victim, thus the sports car driver presented authenticated records from the prior conviction of the muscle car driver, which are true documents and not hearsay.
Hearsay is out of court statements, which are not admissible in court.
Therefore, from the information gathered from my research, option B was the best answer choice.

A varicocele is an enlargement of the veins inside the scrotum due to malfunctioning of valves within the veins in the scrotum. Varicoceles can occur on either the left or the right side of the scrotum, however they most commonly occur on the left side because of the function of the veins on the left side to keep blood flowing through to the heart.
A varicocele on the right side is not a serious medical condition, however it is an indication of an abnormality. Right side varicoceles may indicate a blockage in the abdomen resulting from factors such as blood clots, tumors, or problems with internal organs. In some cases, it may indicate the of adrenocortical carcinoma. Adrenocortical carcinoma are cancerous tumors that affect the adrenal glands.
A doctor may request further abdominal tests including a CT scan to check abdominal masses or tumors.

From my research and also learning that the patient had the varicocele on the right side of the scrotum, if is advisable for him to undergo an abdominal CT scan to ensure there are no other conditions such as tumor or masses in the abdomen.
For this reason, I chose B as my final answer.

column16:
I chose A as my final answer after doing some research.
From my research, the car buyer is likely to win, if they decide to sue the car dealer. The car dealer can be charged with either fraudulent concealment or fraudulent misrepresentation.
Fraudulent concealment is the purposeful act of concealing or failing to disclose facts relevant to a transaction to defraud or mislead another party. This can happen in a contract, where one person doesn't tell the other person something they should know. In proving fraudulent concealment, the person who was misled must show that the fact was important, that the other person knew about it, that they meant to hide it, and that the person who was misled suffered because of it.
Fraudulent misrepresentation can be defined as any type of false statement or lie that is used to trick an individual into an agreement. The misrepresentation may occur in many ways, including written words, spoken words, gestures motion like a nod.
For example, if an automobile dealer lies regarding the accident history of a used vehicle in order to get an individual to sign a purchase contract, then it may be considered fraudulent misrepresentation. 
From the definitions of fraudulent misrepresentation and concealment, it is evident that the car buyer has a case and could win if the decide to sue the car dealer as long as they can prove the all the elements of fraudulent misrepresentation.

Therefore, I chose A as my final answer.

The Fifth amendment states that no person shall be held to answer for a capital, or otherwise infamous crime, unless on a presentment or indictment of a grand jury, except in cases where they shall be compelled in any criminal case to be a witness against himself. 
The Fifth Amendment grants defendants several kinds of rights, particularly the right to resist incriminating oneself. Witnesses can plead the fifth in either civil or criminal proceedings to assert the privilege against self-incrimination.
In civil proceedings, a defendant may be able to invoke the fifth amendment and refuse to answer questions during depositions or trial if they believe that testimony can incriminate them.

Therefore the woman invoking her right to remain silent to avoid self-incrimination is legal and valid.
This is why I chose A as my final answer.

column16:
I chose A as my final answer after doing some research.
First, I looked at the definition of Undue influence which refers to a situation where one person takes advantage of their position of power or trust to manipulate or pressure another person into making a decision that they would not have otherwise made. It usually involves exerting an unfair amount of control over someone, undermining their ability to make an independent and voluntary choice.
In my research, I found that undue influence can arise in various contexts, such as contracts, wills, and transactions.

Since there is a high degree of trust and reliance in certain relationships such as between parent and a child, or a solicitor and a client, if one of the partners in such a relationship unduly influences the other, there is a high chance of undue influence.
However, inadequate consideration refers to a situation where the value of the consideration exchanged in a contract is not fair or reasonable under the circumstances of the agreement. 

In order to prove undue influence, a party must show that the other party to the contract is a person with weaknesses which makes him or her likely to be affected by such persuasion, and that the party exercising the persuasion is someone in a special relationship with the victim that makes the victim especially susceptible to such persuasion.
In this question, the daughter has a special relationship with her mother and she even threaten her mother with ceasing to visit her if she did not sign the contract willing the house to her at a value of $100,000.
It is very clear that, due to the relationship of the mother and daughter and the fact that the daughter forced her mother into a contract against her will, this contract will therefore be invalid under Undue influence.
This is the reason why I chose A, as my final answer.

column16:
I chose A as my final answer after doing some research.
From the agreement signed between the plumbing supply company and the property manager the location of delivery and terms of payment were not outlined in it. 
However, the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) law applies to this kind of agreement between merchant or a seller and a buyer.
Under UCC law article 2-308. Absence of specified place for delivery, it states that unless otherwise agreed:
(a) the place for delivery of goods is the seller's place of business or if he has none his residence;
(b) in a contract for sale of identified goods which to the knowledge of the parties at the time of contracting are in some other place, that place is the place for their delivery; and
(c) documents of title may be delivered through customary banking channels.

Also, under UCC law article 2-310. Open Time for Payment or Running of Credit; Authority to Ship Under Reservation, it states that unless otherwise agreed:
(a) payment is due at the time and place at which the buyer is to receive the goods even though the place of shipment is the place of delivery; and
(b) if the seller is authorized to send the goods he may ship them under reservation, and may tender the documents of title, but the buyer may inspect the goods after their arrival before payment is due unless such inspection is inconsistent with the terms of the contract (Section 2-513).

Taking into consideration these articles of the UCC law, it was clear to me that answer A was the best option.

column16:
I chose B as my final answer after doing some research.
First, let’s look at the definition of hearsay. Hearsay is an out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of whatever it asserts, which is then offered in evidence to prove the truth of the matter. In general, hearsay evidence is not admissible in court.
However, hearsay maybe admissible in court if an exception applies.
There are many exceptions to the hearsay rule, however, I would like to focus on the catchall rule.
The catchall exception to the rule against hearsay provides that, evidence of a hearsay statement not included in one of the other exceptions may nevertheless be admissible if it meets the following conditions:
•	It has sound guarantees of trustworthiness.
•	It helps prove a material fact.
•	It is more probative than other equivalent and reasonably obtainable evidence.
•	Its admission would forward the cause of justice.
 
Now considering going back to the statement, it can be observed that the testimony of the officer falls under hearsay rule, since he was informed about the hit-and-run incident by an anonymous driver. The statement from the anonymous driver to the officer is definitely hearsay.
Now, testimony of the officer even though is a hearsay, it may be admissible in court since it considered as an exception because it qualifies under the catchall exception of the rule of hearsay. This is because it has a probative value and can be prejudice against the defendant as it puts him as the driver of the hit-and-run car.

Looking at the fact that, the officer’s testimony is more prejudice than probative in value, I think it should be dismissed and this is why I chose B as my final answer.

Acute otitis media is also known as an ear infection of the middle-ear, is an infection that occurs in the middle ear, which is located in the air-filled space behind the eardrum that contains the tiny vibrating bones of the ear. This infection is more common in children than in adults. 
Treatment is usually by monitoring or with antibiotics. Acute otitis media, can also but very rarely develop into mastoiditis, which is bacterial infection in your mastoid — the big bone behind your ear.
Some of the symptoms of mastoiditis in children are fever, ear pain, and swelling redness and tender mass behind the ear.
The child was previously given an antibiotic amoxicillin to treat acute otitis media, which initially subsided. It was later observed that the child had a high temperature, which is a fever and an earache behind the ear, which are similar to the symptoms of the acute otitis media developing into a mastoiditis.
The most appropriate step to diagnose and manage this condition in the child is through a CT scan which provides detailed images of inside of the child skull.

Since the child was already provided with antibiotics, the next best step is to perform the CT scan which is option A.

column16:
I chose A as my final answer after doing some research.
First, lets look at a brief definition of a contract, which an agreement between parties, creating mutual obligations that are enforceable by law. Most contracts can either be written or oral and will still be legally enforceable. Some important elements that make a contract legally binding or valid are:
•	Offer– One party promising to do something, or conversely, promising to refrain from doing a particular action which could be in the form of a written contract.
•	Acceptance– The unambiguous nature by which an agreement is solidified. This may be done verbally, or through performance or deed.
•	Awareness– Both parties acknowledge the contract agreement exists.
•	Consideration– When something of value is offered in exchange for the above-stated action or inaction; the value that induces the parties to enter into the contract.
•	Capacity– Individuals must have the ability to reasonably have a mutual understanding of what entering a contract agreement means; individuals compromised by, for example, alcohol, may be found to lack capacity with respect to contract law.
•	Legality– Valid contracts must fall in line with existing laws.

Generally, it is advisable to have your contract in writing to ensure both parties understand their obligations. It is easier to enforce a written contract than a verbal contract. Some examples of contracts required to be in writing include:
•	Mortgage agreements
•	Lease agreements
•	Online purchases
•	Sign-up agreements
•	Insurance
•	Promissory notes

From the statement, it is clearly observed that the uncle wrote to his nephew offering him the antique store for a price, for which the nephew wrote him back in acceptance of the offer. It can also be observed that verbally the uncle confirmed that the owner of the building agreed to the lease transfer which was one of the conditions for the Uncle selling the store to his nephew.
Even though the Uncle intended to instruct his lawyer to create a written document, there has already been an exchange of an agreement in writing which was accepted by both parties, which is a binding contract.
Therefore, the nephew can sue his Uncle for a breach of contract.
For this reason, I chose A as my final answer after researching.

First, considering the patient’s medical history of being hypertensive, hyperlipidemic, diabetic, and a smoking history, along with his non-healing ulcer on his toe, it can be drawn that he is suffering from peripheral artery disease (PAD).
Peripheral artery disease is a condition whereby narrowed arteries reduce blood flow to the arms or legs. In PAD of the legs, usually the legs do not receive enough blood flow, which can cause pain in the leg when walking.
Some of the symptoms of PAD are:
•	Numbness or weakness in the legs.
•	 Painful cramping in either one or both the hips, thighs, or calf muscles after walking or climbing stairs.
•	Ulcers or open sores on the toes or legs that won’t heal.
From the sentence, it can be observed that the patient showed signs of these symptoms and clearly confirms he has PAD.
From the sentence it can also be noted that an ankle-brachial index test was carried out on the patient. This is a simple and quick test to check for PAD.
From his results, the index for both his legs were less than 0.90, which indicates or confirms PAD.
The best next step of management for this condition and from the observation of symptoms is to carry out a non-invasive test called angiography to view the arteries in the legs.
I did not choose B, because of his severe symptoms and this is a non-healing ulcer so initiating oral antibiotics would not be the best next step.
Therefore, from my research above, I decided to go with choice A as my final answer.

I chose B as my final answer after doing some research.
First, let’s look at what are the Miranda rights or Miranda warning. Miranda rights or warnings refers to the warnings or rights a police officer is required to give to a detainee based on constitutional requirements. These rights are usually read or given to a detainee when they are in police custody or before interrogation about an alleged crime.
Miranda rights include the following:
•	You have the right to remain silent.
•	Anything you say can and will be used against you in court of law.
•	You have the right to an attorney.
•	If you cannot afford an attorney, one will be appointed for you.
Miranda rights guarantees your Fifth Amendment right under the US constitution which protects a person from being compelled to be a witness against yourself (Self-incrimination). This reduces the likelihood that a criminal suspect ultimately gives a coerced confession.

From the passage, a Police officer started to recite the Miranda rights to both accusers when Accuser A spoke up to confession. At the point, Accuser A had revoked their protection under the Fifth Amendment while Accuser B was still protected as he was still silent after the Miranda rights were being recited.

Now, let’s look at the definition of a confession. A confession is an out-of-court statement made by a suspect in which he or she voluntarily, knowingly, and intelligently acknowledges that he or she committed or participated in the commission of a crime. 
It should also be noted that, any confession given while a person is under arrest or in custody of law enforcement will not be admissible in court.
Looking at the definition of a confession, it clear that it is a hearsay statement which under the hearsay rule is prohibited from being admitted as evidence in court of law.

Considering all the statements above from my research and details from the passage, Accused B not responding or objecting to the accusatory statement of Accused A is impermissible as evidence since under the Miranda rights Accused B has the right to remain silent and has no duty or obligation not respond to any accusations.
This is why I chose B as my final answer.

The scores of GCS can be interpreted as follows, a score of 15 means you are fully awake and a score of 8 or less means you’re in a coma. 
Since the patient had a GCS score of 10, means he moderate traumatic brain injury. 
A Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST) scan is an ultrasonic scan which is used to detect free intra-abdominal or pericardial fluid in a trauma patient.
The FAST scan on the patient did not provide any clear diagnosis, therefore further examination had to be carried out on the patient.
From a pelvic radiography, it was however observed that there was a fracture in both ischial rami or the pelvic bones. Pelvic fractures may cause shock, extensive internal bleeding, and damage to internal organs. 
A non-invasive exam which be used to evaluate patients with blunt trauma is the CT scan. CT scans have a high sensitivity and specificity in blunt abdominal injury helping to identify any free fluid or damage to organs in the abdomen.
These the abdominal CT scan is non-invasive procedure which can provide results of any abdominal injuries as compared to the diagnostic peritoneal lavage (DPL) which is invasive.
Therefore, I chose B as my final answer.

First, let us look at the definition of a contract. A contract is an agreement between two parties, that creates an obligation to perform (or not perform) a particular duty that are enforceable by law. The elements required for an agreement to be a legally enforceable contract are:
1.	An Offer.
2.	An Acceptance.
3.	Mutual Consideration.
4.	Legal Parties.
5.	Legal Purpose.
Contracts are also promises that the law will enforce. Contracts arise when a duty comes into existence, because of a promise made by one of the parties. 
If a promise is breached, the law provides remedies to the harmed party, often in the form of monetary damages, or in limited circumstances, in the form of specific performance of the promise made.

From the passage, the executive received a formal signed decree from the corporation's board of directors which stated that whenever the executive chooses to retire, the corporation would provide him a monthly pension of $2,000 for the rest of his life. This can be considered as a contract, as the board of directors have promised to perform a duty which has been formally written and signed, therefore it is enforceable by law.

With this promise on the table, the executive was convinced to go on retirement and purchase the vehicle which he planned to use for his travels. In the terms of the signed formal decree, it did not mention any changes to the lifetime pension to the executive in case of any unforeseeable changes in circumstances.
As the company promised the executive a lifetime monthly pension of $2,000, any cessation to this can be considered as a breach in contract.

Based on the above-mentioned points, the executive could prevail if he files a lawsuit against the corporation for breach of contract.
This is why I chose A as my final answer.

I chose B as my final answer after doing research.
First, I used some of the guidelines from AI, by researched what is subclavian steal syndrome and what are its typical symptoms.
Subclavian steal syndrome(SSS) can be described as a condition where an artery takes or “steals” blood to your arm instead of sending it to your brain. This is due to the narrowing or blockage in your subclavian artery, usually the left one which sends blood to your arm on that side.
Some of the risk factors of the subclavian steal syndrome include:
•	Family history of vascular diseases
•	Smoking
•	Diabetes 
•	Hypertension.
Some of the symptoms of the SSS are more likely to occur when you feel pain in your arm after an exercise or when you turn your head suddenly to the side.
Other symptoms include:
•	Vertigo.
•	Visual loss or blurry vision.
•	Dizziness.
•	Tingling, numbness, pain, or tiredness in your arm.
Now if we go back to the passage, you will notice that the patient felt fatigue in his left arm after performing his job as a woodworker. He also complained of dizziness and vertigo, which are all clear symptoms of someone affected by subclavian steal syndrome.
Even with this, we cannot conclude that the patient is suffering from SSS without some further investigation.
One exam used by healthcare providers to diagnose SSS is by measure the blood pressure of both your arms. If the blood pressure for both arms is not the same, with one arm having a pressure difference of about 15 mmHg more than the other arm, then this indicates the patient is highly having Subclavian artery syndrome.
During the examination of the pulses of the arms it was noticed that the left side had a relatively reduced brachial and radial pulse as compared to the right arm. 
This therefore confirms that a subclavian steal syndrome could be occurring on the left arm of the woodworker and that is why his left arm gets fatigued.
With the above analysis, I conclude that, my final right answer for this question is B.

First, let’s look at what is a quitclaim deed. A quitclaim deed releases a person’s interest in a property without stating the nature of the person’s interest or rights, and with no warranties of that person’s interest or rights in the property. 
A quitclaim deed makes no assurance that the grantor actually has an ownership interest in a property; it merely states that if the grantor does, they release those ownership rights. As a result, when accepting a quitclaim deed, the buyer of a property accepts the risk that the grantor of the deed may not have a valid ownership interest in the property.

In the passage, Zoey and Xavier signed a written agreement where Xavier would pay Zoey an amount of money in exchange for Zoey to provide Xavier with a quitclaim deed ensuring the apple orchard is transferred to Xavier without any warranties. 
From the court litigation regarding the rightful claim of the apple orchard between Zoey and Zane, the court ruled in favor of Zane being the rightful owner.

Xavier who already had a quitclaim deed with Zoey was unaware of the court ruling in favor of Zane being the rightful owner of the orchard.
Since the quitclaim does not make any assurance that the grantor has ownership interest in the property, Zoey can’t use this to take legal action against Xavier for withholding subsequent payments.

However, looking at the fact that after the signed written agreement, between Xavier and Zoey, Xavier made a first payment to Zoey. This can be seen as acceptance to the agreement as he made the payment which is accepted by Zoey.
Therefore, Xavier withholding the rest of the payment, could be considered as a breach in contract.
For the reason, I chose B as my final answer for this question.

From the passage, the original agreement between the property owner and the construction company was a signed written agreement.
We are not told if there was a no-oral-modification clause in the signed agreement which prohibits the modification of the contract verbally.

Now, it is worth noting that all states in the U.S have a business law, generally know as a statute of frauds, which is a common law that requires certain types of contracts to be in writing to be legally enforceable agreement. The types of contracts that must be in writing are:
•	Contracts in consideration of marriage (including prenuptial agreements).
•	Contracts that cannot be completed within one year.
•	Real estate contracts (the sale of land, etc.).
•	Executor/estate.
•	Sale of goods that are $500 or more (which may be covered under the Uniform Commercial Code).
•	Surety (an agreement to pay someone's debts which often involves a promisor and a guarantor).
Construction contracts are not expressly covered by statute of frauds however contract law treats construction contracts as falling within the terms and some categories in the statute of frauds.
From the explanations above and from the passage, even though we do not know if there was a no-oral-modification clause in the signed agreement, we can consider that the signed agreement falls within the statute of fraud. Therefore, the construction company violated the contractual obligation of the signed contract with the property owner, even though there was an oral modification.
For this reason, I chose A as my final answer.

I started off by researching some of the questions the AI used as a guideline. I searched for what is a small bowel obstruction (SBO). Small Bowel Obstruction is a partial or complete blockage of your small intestines. 
SBO is usually caused by scar tissue (abdominal adhesions) from previous surgeries, hernia or cancerous tumors. 
Some common symptoms of small bowl obstruction are:
•	Abdominal pain or cramping.
•	Nausea and vomiting of dark green or yellow bile.
•	Bloating.
•	If fluid and air cannot advance beyond the obstruction, patients can no longer pass gas or have a bowel movement (obstipation) or severe constipation.

The management and treatment of patients with SBO is urgent fluid resuscitation with intravenous fluids and electrolytes to treat dehydration as patients are often fluid deplete. 
Next is for the patient to be made nil-by-mouth, thus, not to eat or drink anything through the mouth and to have a nasogastric tube passed through the nostrils to the stomach to decompress or suction out fluids from the stomach.

From the passage looking at the symptoms of the patient such as abdominal pain, vomiting bile which does not contain blood, abdominal X-ray showing dilated bowel loops with multiple air-fluid levels, it is evident that his has SBO.
Since the ED provided fluid resuscitation which is one of the steps to managing this condition, the next appropriate step is to perform a nasogastric tube decompression to suction out fluid and gases from the stomach.
This is why I chose B as my final answer.

From the passage it is very clear and evident that the salesman worked tirelessly and effortlessly to secure an order for a supercomputer from a client. However, the salesman was not paid a commission for this deal.

Now, let us look at what is a commission and if there are any state or federal laws governing this. A sales commission is an amount of money paid to a salesperson or representative based on the number of sales made in a pay period.
There are no federal or state laws requiring commissions. There are also no federal laws regarding the payment of commissions following termination of employment.
Some states expressly prohibit employers from withholding commissions that were earned before the termination of employment. 
However, in this passage we are not told which state the salesman lives in, so we are unable to use state laws in his defense.
An employment contract determines the compensation plan between the salesperson and the employer. The employment contract describes employee compensation, the amount and timing of commission payments.
If a case comes down to litigation and there are no state laws governing the sales commission, then the terms of commission stated in employment contract or agreement is used.

From the passage, it is explicitly stated that in order to qualify for a commission from the sale of a supercomputer, the salesperson must be an active employee of the company at the time the invoice is issued to the client.
The salesman’s employment was terminated on March 15, while the manufacturer finally billed the client of the supercomputer on March 31. As at the time the client was billed, the salesman was no more an employee of the manufacturing company and therefore as per the terms of his contract will not be paid the commission on the sale of the supercomputer.
For this reason, I chose B as my final answer.

column16:
I found this task particularly tough to consider initially, as the laws around surveillance in public/commercial/private domain are quite different in the UK than USA. It seemed from research that the reliability of infrared to identify an individual was slim, but at the same time the notion of it infringing upon the constitutional right to face accusers didn't make sense based on that. In addition, many of the resources referred to a case of infrared use in identifying details around an accused's property to prove a crime, which is not quite relevant in this case as it's a commercial, trespassing case.
Also, we know that an expert has verified the reliability of infrared imaging, but we dont know in what context or scale the image was taken, so whilst infrared might be reliable, it would depend upon other factors not mentioned in the description. Ultimately it is up the jury to decide and draw their own conclusions so i somewhat reluctantly went with option B.
